direction.raw_text: . POKROVSKOE--NIGHT CLOSE--Expert fingers--female, unlovely, capable--shape a small lump of dough which, with some shreds of cabbage, becomes a filled bun called a pirozhok . . . which is now placed on a baking tray to join rows of pirozhoki ready for the oven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- One hand opens the oven, and, mittened by an apron, removes a tray of perfectly baked pirozhoki, which the other hand replaces with the fresh tray . . . slightly burning itself on a knuckle.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FEBRUARY 1872 POKROVSKOE, KONSTANTIN LEVIN'S ESTATE 300 MILES SOUTH OF MOSCOW

direction.raw_text: Agafia sucks her knuckle and checks what's cooking on the stove-top. She is the cook-housekeeper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He needs to come in if he's to wash himself. A Kitchen Maid at the sink obediently dries her hands on her apron. A dozing dog, Laska, pricks up her ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's snowing. The Kitchen Maid, shawled, with a lantern, makes her way across the yard towards the cowshed, a short distance, and pushes open the frozen door. Laska is at her heels, but is made to stay outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COWSHED, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME--NIGHT The herd stirs at the lantern light. The bull, Berkut, with a ring through his nose, snorts as the girl goes by. At the back of the shed a cow is calving. Levin is midwifing, sleeves pulled back, blood and slime up to his elbows. He is 34. His steward, Vasili, holds up a lantern. Levin pulls carefully at the emerging forefeet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good girl . . . good girl, Pava. The calf's head emerges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Agafia Mishaylovna says dinner's like to spoil. The calf enters the world like a diver. Levin is feeling great pride and pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . her father's colour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worth coming home for, Konstantin Dmitrich!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I stayed too long in Moscow. The cow nuzzles and licks her calf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DINING ROOM, POKROVSKOE--NIGHT Cleaned up, in a smock shirt, Levin bites hungrily into a pirozhok, talking. He has a book on a book-rest. Agafia ladles soup for him. Three generations of family portraits look down on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . She's a beauty. That's twelve cows sired by Berkut!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So one of you is doing what the good Lord made you for. Levin evades, ducks into spooning up soup, finding his place in his book. Agafia goes out. Alone, Levin closes the book and stares into himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (MOSCOW)-- DAY CLOSE--Expert fingers scrape a cut-throat razor across a lathered cheek . . . and again, skirting luxuriant facial hair on pampered skin.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, OBLONSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, OBLONSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, OBLONSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY There is a door to the landing and a door to the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince Stepan Oblonsky-- Stiva to his friends--is 34 and liked by every- body. A barber comes in every morning to shave him. His valet, Matvey, is older and almost a friend. He holds up an enormous pear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What should I do with this? Oblonsky puts the barber on hold to have a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you find it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In your hat. Your Excellency. Oblonsky thinks about it, lets the barber finish. He stands and removes his dressing gown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes . . . I picked it up somewhere for Daria Alexandrovna and the children. Matvey is ready with Oblonsky's shirt, which he puts over his master's head like a horse's collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a sloping lineup of five children, aged eight, five, four, three and two, dressed and brushed for presentation to their mother, Princess Daria Oblonsky, known as Dolly . . . who we now see is heavily pregnant. Stand- ing by is a French governess, Mlle. Roland, and a Nurse. Mlle. Roland is buxom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolly picks up the youngest, Vasya, to kiss him and hands him to the Nurse, and kisses the others in ascending order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bonjour, Lili; bonjour, Masha; bonjour, Grisha; bonjour, Tanya. Who's coming to see Grandmama?
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME-- DAY Oblonsky, dressed now and holding a cup of coffee, checks from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolly, in furs, the four youngest children and the Nurse, who carries Vasya, all wrapped up against the cold weather, have come out of the house to a waiting sleigh, as noisy as starlings, bickering, competing, reprimanding. The Oblonsky's Coachman assists, with a rug to spread across knees. Oblonsky hands his coffee to Matvey and lights a small cigar. He detours to take a sugared almond from a dish of sweets, and leaves the room . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tanya is at her lessons with Mlle. Roland. When Oblonsky's face appears smiling round the door, Tanya jumps up and runs to him, greeting him, laughing, kissing his face, hanging on his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Tanruchoshka! Mind my cigar. He pops the sugared almond into her mouth and puts a conspiratorial finger to his lips. Mlle. Roland, who has stood up for him, clucks in reprimand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be good today. I'm off. Tanya runs back to her seat and bends to her schoolbook. Oblonsky looks Mlle. Roland in the eye. He moves his head slightly, unmistakably ask- ing her to come outside. Mlle. Roland moves her eyes at him in humorous reproach. Clearly, this is familiar ground. Oblonsky closes the door behind him. mlle. roland (PAUSE) Read the chapter carefully. I'll come back to test you on it . . . Read it twice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (ST. PETERSBURG)--DAY
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --Pretty fingers put on several rings, and then pick up a Faberge jade paper-knife to slit an envelope and withdraw a letter.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: PETERSBURG 400 MILES NORTH OF MOSCOW 8 INT
ANNA'S BOUDOIR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG 400 MILES NORTH OF MOSCOW 8 INT. ANNA'S BOUDOIR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY It is early in the day. Anna's maid, Annushka, has been dressing Anna. Annushka is young, loyal, modest. Anna is at her dressing-table-bureau, which is host to at least two pho- tographs of a small boy (Serozha) and a child's unframed drawing of "Maman." As she starts reading the letter, Anna's eyes frown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (LINEN CLOSET)--DAY Oblonsky and Mlle. Roland in a passionate embrace, vertical, clothed.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FLASH BACK, VERY SHORT, ALMOST SUBLIMINAL-- INT

direction.raw_text: Anna turns the page, reads on, concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LINEN CLOSET, OBLONSKY HOUSE--DAY Still kissing, Oblonsky hoists up her skirts.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FLASH BACK-- SHORT, A BEAT OR TWO-- INT

direction.raw_text: Anna turns to the second page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM LEVEL, OBLONSKY HOUSE--NIGHT Oblonsky, coming in quietly and late from a night on the town, enters his dressing room. He stops. He smiles a foolish apologetic smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolly is waiting for him, shocked, enraged, holding out a billet-doux on pink paper: a love note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna speaks as in exasperation to a naughty child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tsk, oh . . . Stiva!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . and Dolly found a note from the governess. Anna is speaking to her husband "confidentially." Karenin, a busy man, drains his coffee cup and hands it (as with Oblonsky and Matvey) to his valet, Korney, who bows and withdraws. Karenin continues transferring papers from his desk to his portfolio . . . Which done, he nods to his private secretary, Mikhail Slyudin, who comes forward to receive it, bows and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well . . . ? Karenin is twenty years older than Anna and a senior figure in govern- ment. He has an unattractive reedy voice and is pleased with himself as a model of probity. He has the habit of cracking his knuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stiva wants me to come to Moscow . . . to persuade Dolly to forgive him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm to be deprived of my wife so that adul- tery may be forgiven? I can't excuse him just because he's your brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's for Dolly's sake too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (has to go) I have four committees today . . . There is another interruption: Serozha, aged seven and a half, and his tutor, Vasily Lukich, enter for a ritual "good morning." Serozha is a little frightened of his father, but the mother and son are in love. Anna goes straight to Serozha, her heart lifted, to hug him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, good!--I have the world waiting for me, there's never time to look at your exercises!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergei Alexeyich is doing very well, Your Excellency.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a button missing) Tsk-tsk, who put this shirt on you? Never mind. I'll come and hear you read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow, perhaps. Thank you, Lukich-- perhaps tomorrow. Lukich bows. Anna goes with Serozha, relinquishing him finally. She closes the door on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei, do you think nine years of mar- riage and children should count for nothing against a . . . an infatuation? Karenin cracks his knuckles, concedes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Very well. (kisses her hand) But sin has a price, you may be sure of that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblonsky has been bunking down on his couch. He moans and groans. He gets up and tries the door to the bedroom. It's locked. He knocks timidly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolly . . . please think of the children . . . He listens hopefully. The other door, leading to the upper landing, is opened violently by Dolly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think of the children! Their lives are ruined now! She slams the door behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblonsky comes out of his dressing room to see the main bedroom door slammed. He attempts to go in but the door is locked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Dolly . . . I beg you . . . Matvey come to the top of the stairs with a telegram.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Telegram. Should I send up the barber?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, just the razor. Oblonsky tears open the telegram.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, sir, things will shape them- selves, you'll see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My sister Anna's coming tomorrow. We're saved.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: BEDROOM LEVEL, OBLONSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: Inner doors open and Oblonsky comes out of his private office. He is his genial self. Everyone in the general office-- minor officials, clerks-- stands up for him and bows. Oblonsky is wearing government uniform--green coat with gold embroidery on the collar--instead of his own coat. Oblonsky is helped out of one coat into the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some man came without an appointment, Your Excellency . . . waiting outside. Oblonsky opens the door to look. Levin is sitting waiting on a bench, wear- ing a sheepskin coat, cap and scuffed boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin! Where did you disappear? He seizes Levin and kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm very anxious to see you. I need your advice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, then, come into my room. Oblonsky leads Levin back through the general office, where everyone stands up again. Levin's sheepskin and boots attract curious glances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is my oldest friend, Konstantin Dmit- rich Levin! Someone send word I'll be a few minutes late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblonsky leads Levin inside and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been hard at it. Sit down. Levin undoes his coat and sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hard at what exactly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, we're overwhelmed with work!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh--paperwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paperwork is the soul of Russia. Farming is only the stomach. When am I going to come and shoot some snipe? Seeing the clothes Levin is wearing, he laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but look at you, in Western clothes you told me you'd never wear again. Some- thing's up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I'm in love. I've come back to propose. Have you guessed who she is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rolls his eyes comically) I have a suspicion. Why didn't you propose when you were here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I decided it was impossible. Kitty is of the heavens, an angel, and I am of the earth-- but then I thought and thought, and . . . there's no life for me without her! . . . Do I have a chance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course you do. The Shcherbatskys are giving a soiree this evening. Get there early before the crowd. If I may suggest . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything! What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: New boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. Anything else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd better have dinner together. Come on, we'll meet later at l'Angleterre. Or do you prefer the Hermitage? Oblonsky ushers Levin back into the general office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . Everyone stands up as before. The Doorkeeper produces Oblonsky's top- coat and helps him into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No--five-thirty at l'Angleterre--I owe them more than the Hermitage, so it wouldn't be fair to withdraw my custom. (taking his hat) Boots, and a coat. And a proper hat. He ushers Levin out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Firstly, a Moscow street scene, busy with people going about their business, on foot and in conveyances. Secondly, Levin approaches L'Angleterre in his new fur-collared coat, top hat and boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . L'ANGLETERRE RESTAURANT, MOSCOW-- NIGHT Oblonsky and Levin preside over the debris of three dozen oysters, with champagne in a bucket to hand. Oblonsky is in a maudlin mood, afloat on champagne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so unfair. You marry for love, you're a good husband. Children arrive. Years depart. And all of a sudden your wife is tired, her hair is thin, her body . . . while you yourself still have your . . . vigour . . . and you find yourself distracted by a pretty woman . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me, but I find that incomprehen- sible . . . As though I'd leave this restaurant and steal a roll from a baker's shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you know, a freshly baked roll . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I'm talking about love, and you're talk- ing about . . . your appetite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Easily confused. Now look, do you know Count Vronsky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who? No. Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's your rival. He turned up from St. Petersburg after you left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to worry about him. He's one of those rich, good-looking cavalry offi- cers who've got nothing to do but make love to pretty women . . . A waiter arrives to remove the oyster shells, while an Elderly Waiter places a bowl of soup in front of Levin and a lobster in front of Oblonsky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cabbage soup?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Potage aux choux a la Russe, as the gentle- man ordered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's what I wanted. Oblonsky laughs. The Waiter departs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Understand that for me, tonight is a ques- tion of life and death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Kostya! Kitty would be mad to refuse you. And Dolly is on your side, you know. She says her sister Kitty was always meant to be your wife and will be. Levin jumps up in elation, collects himself, and sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolly said that? I've always thought your Dolly's a gem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, she is, she is . . . (THOUGHTFULLY) I loved her to distraction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (ST. PETERSBURG)--NIGHT A little out of focus and further obscured by puffs of steam, the wheels of a locomotive and its tender plus a carriage or two, with part of the superstructure--the whole kit and caboodle turning out to be a rich child's table-top model railway--go by the Camera like a WIPE revealing the momentarily gigantic face of Anna . . . who is crouching down to watch the toy go by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Serozha is at present snivelling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because that's where Aunt Dolly lives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you, Serozha. She's not well. I must go to see her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, don't make Mama cry. I'll be back before you know, and bring you a present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't want a present. I want you to stay. Anna is on the brink of tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh . . . my little Kutik . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What present?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's better. She dabs her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KARENIN HOUSE--NIGHT Kapitonich, the Karenins' Hall Porter, an "old soldier," comes out of the house to where a private carriage is waiting. The coachman is Konrad. Anna comes out with Annushka, who has a large soft bag containing everything her mistress needs for the journey. Kapitonich holds the carriage door for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOVING TRAIN--NIGHT Anna has a window seat. Next to her is Annushka. In the opposite window seat is Countess Vronsky, at sixty losing the battle to keep her youthful beauty. She has a lap dog (and perhaps a Faberge-topped walking cane). Next to her is her Maid. Anna is not happy to be leaving. She holds a small framed photo of Sero- zha, which she then puts away in her red bag. Countess Vronsky smiles at her. Anna wipes her eyes, explains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the first time I've left my little boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you are leaving your son and I am return- ing to mine. I am Countess Vronsky. Anna knows the name. countess vronsky (cont'd) I've been in St. Petersburg for the christen- ing of a granddaughter--my elder son mar- ried Princess Chirkov. You're a charming creature. Why don't I know you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never been in Moscow society, really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you know my name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've heard you mentioned . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talked about, you mean. Ah, love! Anna, found out, smiles tentatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was it love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always. My sons are ashamed of me. But I'd rather end up wishing I hadn't than end up wishing I had--wouldn't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . I don't know . . . Anna looks at the snow on the window. She is unsettled by the conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOSCOW--NIGHT A sleigh (i.e., a cab) brings Levin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ENTRANCE HALL, SHCHERBATSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT The Hall Porter lets Levin into the house. A Footman takes Levin's hat and coat. Levin is uneasy--he seems to be first to arrive. He decides he has come too early. He pulls his coat back from the Footman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll come back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Princess Ekaterina (Kitty) Shcherbatsky is eighteen. Eager to see who has arrived, she hurries from the direction of the reception room and looks down into the entrance hall in time to see Levin snatch his hat back from the Footman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Konstantin!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm too early.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Come up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty runs off out of Levin's view. He flings his hat and coat at the Foot- man and runs up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RECEPTION ROOM, SHCHERBATSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT Levin hurries in and finds Kitty seated prettily in a "receiving" pose. She is alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at me! I'm receiving for Papa and Maman who are late to dress. It's my first reception. Levin plays along, kissing her hand elaborately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Princess Ekaterina! Delighted, delighted!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so pleased you were able to be with us, Konstantin Dmitrich!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty . . . you look . . . you look--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stiva told us you were back. How long are you staying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. It depends on you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has got ahead of himself. Doors are flung open and the hosts, Prince and Princess Shcherbatsky, and a crowd of guests who have arrived together, are greeting each other. Levin has to make a quick decision, and he makes the wrong one--to go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I mean to say--I came with only one purpose--I want to--will you be my wife? Kitty panics. A wave of Guests is almost upon her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry--sorry--wrong moment--but will you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't. I'm sorry. Kitty flees. Levin seems stunned, surrounded now by greetings, laughter, and servants with trays of drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It was impossible. Prince and Princess Shcherbatsky receive a young married member of Kitty's set, Countess Nordston . . . and introduce Levin, who hears and sees noth- ing. He turns away, leaving the Countess hung out to dry. Levin finds himself face to face with Burisov, a silky Officer in sky blue uniform, who introduces himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burisov. Are you the brother of Nikolai Levin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's in Moscow, he's staying at the Unicorn in Khitrovka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the sort of thing I know. He bows to Levin and turns away to greet someone. Levin reacts, decides to leave. He makes for the door. He nearly collides with someone, gives and receives an apology, and suddenly understands who this man in Guards uniform must be. Levin turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Count Vronsky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Levin pauses awkwardly. Vronsky hesitates, bows and continues on. Levin witnesses Kitty seeing Vronsky approaching, and sees her face light up. Vronsky kisses her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Princess Kitty . . . It's been so long, and yet it seems like yesterday. His banter is lost on her. She laughs happily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was yesterday! Levin turns away and leaves.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ENTRANCE HALL, SHCHERBATSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT
RECEPTION ROOM, SHCHERBATSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: Levin comes out of the grand house where several coaches are waiting. Hum- bled and angry with himself and the world, he takes off his top hat and considers putting his fist through it, but jams it back on his head. A horse- cab comes along. Levin waves it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mean street, an area of poverty and crime. Levin pays off his cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin goes up a dimly lit, dingy staircase. Snatches of MUSIC and SING- ING drift up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin knocks at a door, then louder. The door is flung open. Nikolai Levin is the spirit of consumptive, bohemian radicalism. He peers at Levin, surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Kostya. Nikolai roars with laughter which turns to wheezing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, look at him! You look like a capitalist! (THEN SUSPICIOUSLY) What do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. I came to see you. Nikolai goes back into the room, shouting for "Masha." Levin follows him.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: NIKOLAI'S ROOM, KHITROVA, SAME TIME-- NIGHT
result.heading: NIKOLAI'S ROOM, KHITROVA, SAME TIME-- NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . NIKOLAI'S ROOM, KHITROVA, SAME TIME-- NIGHT Levin sees that he is in a tiny apartment. A Young Woman looks at him fearfully from the inner doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, miss . . . madame . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't talk to her like that. It frightens her. You sound like a magistrate. (shouts at her) More vodka for my brother, quick about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want anything. Masha goes to Nikolai and whispers to him, calming him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm all right. He fills a wineglass with vodka and gulps it greedily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who told you where to find me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A colonel in the Third Department. They're watching you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. They must think I'm dangerous. Levin involuntarily smiles at the self-puffery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you got to smile about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. The day is coming. I gave up my birthright for it. You're on the wrong side of history. Not because privilege is immoral but because it's irrational. Wheezing, he goes for the bottle again. Masha tries to take it from him, appealing to Levin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let go or I'll beat your lights out. He pushes her away and pours himself more vodka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I took Mary Nikolova from a brothel but I consider her my wife. If her presence offends you you're free to leave. Are you married?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Are you waiting to fall in love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Romantic love will be the last illu- sion of the old order. You should marry one of your peasants. Levin's reaction is almost violent, surprising Nikolai.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I damn well should!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (toasts, casually) The brotherhood of man. Levin recovers himself. He takes out his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nikolai, you have to see a doctor. Then come and stay with me at Pokrovskoe till you get your health back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With my wife? Levin becomes flustered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you . . . or go abroad to a spa. I'll send you more if that's what you . . . Masha reaches for the money Levin has put on the table. Nikolai knocks her hand away. He throws the banknotes at Levin. He coughs himself into a paroxysm. Levin tries to embrace him. Nikolai throws him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about the brotherhood of brothers? Masha snatches up the banknotes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a scattering of people of all classes on the platform waiting for the arriving train. By the entrance/exit gate, a Guards Officer stands holding a bouquet. The Stationmaster stands by. A strip of faded red carpet has been laid on the planks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The private coach will stop opposite the carpet. The Guards Officer nods. He sees Vronsky arriving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, what's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Austrian royalty on their honeymoon. I've got them for four days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bad luck. What do they like? Art?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's the train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky moves closer to the slowing train, scanning the windows going by.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: PLATFORM, THE ARRIVING TRAIN, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: The Guards Officer and the Stationmaster are disconcerted to see the obvious "private coach" stop seriously short (or long) behind luggage wagons, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll see to it. He hurries away towards the engine. Oblonsky hurries through, relieved not to be late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PLATFORM, SAME TIME--DAY Vronsky is saluted by his mother's Major Domo, a tall man in livery with a cockade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Second carriage, Your Excellency. I'll see to the Countess's luggage and bring it on to the house. Vronsky nods, and makes his way towards the second coach, against the flow of disembarked passengers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Stationmaster speaks to the Engine Driver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Guards Officer with the bouquet stands uncertainly while arriving passengers go past him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Royal Austrian Honeymooners peer anxiously through the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN, SAME TIME-- DAY Countess Vronsky remains sitting. Annushka packs away Anna's blanket and pillow. Anna looks out of the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll come back. Anna moves to the door opening on to the "porch." Vronsky is on the point of entering. He steps back to allow her by. They barely exchange a glance as she passes him, but, simultaneously, each of them looks back. Anna looks away quickly. His look lingers before he turns away to enter the carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna, from her vantage point spots Oblonsky, calls to him. Annushka, with her bag, comes onto the porch and descends to follow her mistress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna steps down to the platform and embraces Oblonsky. They are delighted to see each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't look ashamed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am, I really am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN, SAME TIME-- DAY Countess Vronsky remains in her seat. Vronsky bends at the window, look- ing at Oblonsky and Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course. Oblonsky's sister . . . Karenina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charmante, don't you think? (to her Maid) Wait for me in the carriage. I'll take Tosca. She takes the dog. The Maid leaves with her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . You stayed longer in St. Petersburg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long enough for you to start a little love affair, I hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't think what you're referring to, Maman. He glances back to the window, where Anna turns back to enter the train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Anna turns back, a Railwayman with a hammer for tapping wheels is in her way. He steps back for her with a bow and a "Madame!" Anna glances at him and moves past him. The man taps a wheel, making a ring- ing sound which means the wheel is okay. As Anna mounts the steps, a Train Guard looks up and down the plat- form, holding a green flag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN, SAME TIME-- DAY Anna enters from the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There, Countess, you have found your son and I have found my brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame Karenin has a son, too. It's the first time they have been apart, so she frets about him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me for not recognizing you before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We passed the time telling each other about our sons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I've been hearing all about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That must have been very boring for you. The ringing sound of the wheel-tapper's hammer is faintly audible in Anna's hesitation. Anna shuts off the gallantry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Au revoir, Countess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Au revoir, my dear. Let me kiss your pretty face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess Vronsky does so. Anna turns to offer her hand to Vronsky. As Vronsky takes her hand, the train lurches and moves, unsteadying them both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblonsky-- and everyone still on the platform--is shocked by a dreadful scream and shouting. The train, having moved a few feet, stops. Oblonsky hurries towards the scene of the accident, right opposite the gate. The Station- master overtakes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRACKS, SAME TIME, DAY The Wheel-Tapper lies between the wheels, mangled. Oblonsky joins the horrified onlookers. The Guards Officer arrives, too, with his bouquet. Then Vronsky arrives. He turns to the Guards Officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep your people inside until this has been cleared up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess Vronsky, Vronsky, Anna and Oblonsky, Oblonsky almost in tears, come towards the gate. A Porter follows with Anna's large suitcase, hat- boxes, etc. Annushka has the travelling bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . the sole support of a large family, they say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't anything be done for them? Vronsky glances at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait for me, Maman. Vronsky retraces his steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've you to thank for that. She knows her son. Anna hasn't understood, but when Oblonsky looks back he sees Vronsky with the Stationmaster, taking money from his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a good fellow . . . Anna catches on, doesn't like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you known Count Vronsky long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you like him? He's in love with Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh . . . (PAUSE) But we should be discussing you and Dolly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She scolds him like a naughty boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you got to say for yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've said it all--on my knees--in tears . . . Now I need you to say it. I'm going to the office, so you'll have Dolly to yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be home late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolly pours tea for Anna. Dolly smiles at her wanly-- brightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty's coming by to see you. She's all grown-up, and a bit frightened of you--the belle of St. Petersburg society!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that who I am? Dolly . . . Stiva has told me. Dolly bursts into tears. Anna embraces her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolly, I'm sorry from the bottom of my heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't bear to be with him. And he doesn't care, he's got what he wants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What he wants is you. He loves you, Dolly. You and the children are everything to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are we? And there is room for a governess?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was shameful, disgraceful. But it was not love. It was the animal in man, not the soul. Stiva's remorse is from the soul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about me? Does his remorse make it easier for me?--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you are suffering. But, Dolly, you must tell me . . . is there enough love left in your heart . . . enough to forgive him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I think of them together, I can't for- give him, no!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My poor lamb. So you'd rather accept your fate . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My fate? (OUTRAGED) But I haven't done anything! It's him
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love him, Dolly? Dolly nods tearfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You love him, and he loves you, but you can't forgive, so your lives must continue like this for ever, with both of you wretched. She's winning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna, Kitty, Tanya and Grisha are at a handsome card table where board games, dominoes, cards, etc., are kept. There is a spill of alphabet bricks, each with a letter printed in it. They are spelling out their names in alphabet bricks. Grisha is on Anna's lap pulling at her hair. The spelling business, including misspellings by Grisha, creates a noise of laughter and mock-rebuke. Tanya at the same time is trying to pull a ring from Anna's finger. Kitty is not at all frightened of Anna now; enraptured by her, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grisha, don't pull so hard, you're getting it all in a tangle--and look for another G for
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (She takes off her ring for Tanya) --here, darling, you can wear it till you go
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolly sits apart, embroidering. She looks up at the sound of voices down- stairs, Oblonsky coming home. The children hear their father and abandon the card table, running out to greet him. Dolly stands up to leave by a dif- ferent door, giving Anna a collusive glance. Anna pushes aside the alphabet bricks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's the end of that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you stay for the Bobrishchev's ball, Anna?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh . . . I always feel dull at a ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you ever be dull? Oblonsky arrives in the doorway with Tanya and Grisha hanging on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stiva! Tell Anna she must come to the ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course she must.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He cocks an eye at Anna: how did it go with Dolly? Anna moves her head: upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . and God go with you. Kitty catches the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can introduce me to your new governess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's old! She's a hundred! Which leaves Anna and Kitty alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know why you want me to come. You want everyone to be there because you're sure it's going to be your night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you know? Anna's smile is her acting out a mock-mysteriousness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know everything. She has moved alphabet letters around to spell out VRONSKY. She laughs at Kitty's tearful, joyful nodding, genuinely happy for Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, to be your age again . . . surrounded by that blue mist, like mist on the mountains
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: that clears slowly to reveal the terrifying, beautiful valley you must enter to become grown-up . . . I was eighteen too, when I got married . . . A quiet note of regret hangs in the air between them for a moment before Anna dispels it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With only a lamp or two lit, and the door open, Anna sits alone at the card table, with a neglected book, one hand playing idly with the alpha- bet bricks. Their pleasant clicks are the only sound as she remains lost in thought. She closes her book, marking the place. She is going to go up to bed. She hears the sound of the doorbell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky has been let in spattered with snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . no, Your Excellency . . . He's just gone up. . . . The Princess retired early . . . Is there a message? Vronsky glances up and sees Anna looking down. Their eyes meet. A second passes. Vronsky is about to speak. Anna turns away and moves out of his view, towards further stairs, with her book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEAR POKROVSKOE--DAY Levin is coming home in a sleigh, driven by his one-eyed coachman, Ignat. He is huddled under a bearskin blanket. The house is in sight. The sleigh overtakes a Peasant Woman, Serafina, walking to the house car- rying a big bundle of willow wands strapped to her back: a strong young woman with a handsome face. She stops and bows her head. Levin looks at her. She then looks him in the face. Laska, barking joyfully, races from the house.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: ENTRANCE HALL, OBLONSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . BATHHOUSE, POKROVSKOE-- DAY The bathhouse has a stove which heats water. There is a brazier to create instant steam, but not now. Levin, almost naked, lies on a plank deck, thoughtful, staring at something . . . no, at someone: Serafina, who is put- ting on her clothes. Postcoitum. She has no angst. Dressed, she crosses herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you go to confession? Serafina nods indifferently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God will forgive you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you also, master. He is watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God forgive us then, for committing the act of love. She nods without irony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is merciful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Not according to my deserts, O Lord, but according to thy mercy"--that's a fine prayer. But I'm full of doubt. Sometimes I even doubt that God exists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can there be anything if God didn't make it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. One day science will tell us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's sinful talk if the priest heard you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I won't go to confession.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father built the church. You're con- fessed a while yet. Levin feels outplayed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you bring me something from Moscow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What would you like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soap, the kind wrapped in paper to look pretty, and smelling like for a proper lady. Levin is touched. He nods.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: SOUND OVER--MUSIC OVERLAP WITH THE BALL

direction.raw_text: Kitty enters the Ball, a proper lady. This is a gilded affair, conducted by a Master of Ceremonies. The Host and Hostess are positioned to welcome each guest. Dancing has started-- a waltz. Kitty and her parents enter the ballroom and are received by their hosts. Everything has come together for Kitty--her dress, her hair, her skin, her moment. She radiates happiness. An Officer stands aside to let them pass, openly admiring Kitty, smoothing his moustache. A Youth having trouble with his white tie hurries past but turns back to Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty! May I have a waltz?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may, Boris. I'll save you the third just because it's your first ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're my first conquest. The Master of Ceremonies, Korsunsky, arrives and without permission sweeps her into the waltz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a relaxation to dance with you, Princess. Kitty sees Anna arriving with Oblonsky and gives a little gasp at her God-given beauty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But back to work! Where do you want to be taken?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There. Korsunsky waltzes her brilliantly through the dancers and twirls her to rest in front of a small group including Anna and Oblonsky-- floating Kitty's train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So that your ankles may be seen. Anna appraises Kitty at a glance and gives her a tiny nod signifying top marks. Kitty glows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you, Stiva?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks to Anna, I am a happy man. Would you like to dance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, ask Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No . . . I don't . . . She looks up and sees Vronsky coming straight towards her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on then. Just as Vronsky is about to bow, she takes Oblonsky's arm and he whirls her away. Kitty smiles for Vronsky but his eyes have followed Anna, know- ing she cut him. He remembers himself after an awkward hiatus. Kitty's mother and father are watching from afar. Vronsky obliges. He invites her into the waltz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . this vile, idiotic matchmaking of yours . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For goodness' sake, what have I done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin is a thousand times better than this Petersburg fop. If he had royal blood my daughter wouldn't need him! Vronsky's mind is absent and the waltz ends after only a few steps. He stand waiting for the music to start.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is anything the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. You look . . . as lovely as ever, Princess Kitty. The music starts and they dance on. At the end of the waltz, Vronsky leaves Kitty with her mother, bows and departs. Princess Shcherbatsky is beginning to have doubts. She starts to ask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't ask me, Maman! Boris the Youth pops up to claim his dance. Dancing, Kitty sees Vronsky talking to a couple of Officers. She is anxious but not disillusioned. Grumpy Prince Shcherbatsky is dancing with Countess Nordston.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll dance the mazurka with Kitty, you'll see. I call the mazurka the now-or-never. Anna watches the dancing. She rejects an offer with a smile. She sees Vron- sky and to her discomfort Vronsky looks up and catches her looking. She turns away at once, and notices that ladies are curtseying and men are bowing as the Host and Hostess escort an overweight but glittering young couple towards a decorative buffet in an adjoining salon: the Austrian royal honeymooners . . . attended by the Guards Officer from the station. Anna stands and curtseys as they pass by into the salon . . . where Oblonsky is roaring with laughter, champagne in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . we were shut up in the train for an hour!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna steals a sidelong glance towards Vronsky but he is no longer there. She looks for him among the dancers, smiles at Kitty going by with the enthusiastic, inexpert Boris. Suddenly, Vronsky is at Anna's side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dance with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not used to being spoken to like that by a man I met once at a railway station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dare say, but if I'm not to dance with you, I'm getting out of this operetta and going home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, for Kitty's sake. She gives him her hand. Kitty looks for Vronsky, can't see him, then is taken aback to see him with Anna. Kitty watches Anna dancing. Anna says something which makes Vronsky laugh. Anna laughs. Anna blossoms in front of Kitty's eyes. Vron- sky twirls Anna around and she comes smiling into his arms. It goes on like that. Kitty watches them from within the arms of young men, old men, from the wall. Anna and Vronsky dance slow, they dance fast, gaily, solemnly, gazes locked. Others are noticing too: Countess Nordston, Princess Shcherbatsky, and eagle-eyed matrons. Anna, oblivious, has found a release in herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess Nordston finds Kitty sitting alone. Korsunsky announces the Mazurka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not dancing the mazurka? I won't have it. She pulls Kitty to her feet. countess nordston (cont'd) I'm engaged by General Glub--I give him to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . Korsunsky supervises a large circle of couples who change partners as they go round, with one couple dancing in the middle of the circle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . the lady chooses a lady and a gentleman . . . ! The lady in the middle beckons to Anna and the man who, changing part- ners, happens to be dancing with her. They enter the middle where they have their solo turn as a couple, while the original couple reenter the circum- ference. Anna is flushed with pleasure. Among the surrounding dancers, Vronsky has no eyes for his partner, only for Anna. Kitty, dancing, watches Vronsky incredulous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . and the lady chooses a lady and a gentleman . . . !
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna looks smilingly around the dancing circle and sees Kitty staring at her. Anna "wakes up." Everything which made her drunk makes her sober in the instant. She waits until the change of partners brings Kitty and Vronsky together. She beckons them into the middle. Her own partner expects to re-join the circumference with Anna, but she makes an apology and escapes through the circle, running towards the door. With a howl and clatter, the St. Petersburg express seems to crash through the ballroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An abstract, nightmarish, discordant noise of clattering and howling accompanies unexplained flame--light on wood, glass, iron . . . blackness opens like a door on a blizzard of light, and slams shut. Anna's face, eyes closed, floats ghostlike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna comes to consciousness in the dimly lit carriage, making sense of what seems like a hallucination. Wind and snow batter on the window. The Carriage Stoker, in long coat and cap, deals with the stove, clears frost off a thermometer on the wall. He leaves, opening the door to snow and wind and slamming it behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train "speeds" (35 m.p.h.) through a blizzard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE TRAIN Anna has a reading lamp hooked over her armrest, and a novel. She cuts a page with a paper-knife. But the book cannot hold her. She is reading without taking it in. She turns back a page and tries again, but almost at once she turns to the window where the dark reflection of her face looks back at her. Kitty's face staring as she stared at Anna, betrayed. Anna turns away from the window. The Guard comes through the door, letting in wind and snow, and shuts it. He walks through the carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bologoye! Fifteen minutes. The train is slowing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train clanks to a halt at a small station. Anna (and a few others) get down from the train. She wears a heavy cloak. The wind blows a few snowflakes through the station but the roof keeps off the snow. She is glad of the fresh air. Here and there, men are walking, smoking, laughing together. She feels better. A tall outline of a man in a greatcoat and military cap emerges from the flickering gloom. She catches her breath. He salutes her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I be of service to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know you were . . . Why are you leaving?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know why. I have to be where you are. I can't not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is wrong. If you're a good man, forget everything that happened, as I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll never forget a single thing about you, not a word, not a gesture--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's enough! She climbs the steps on to the porch. At the door to the carriage she pauses. The encounter has left her feeling elated and frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--DAY The train arrives. Vronsky gets down from the train and starts to walk towards Anna's carriage. His German valet, Franz, runs up to him (from second class).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take the luggage home. Franz runs back the other way. Vronsky walks on, then stops when he sees Karenin waiting on the platform, smiling and going forward to hand Anna down the steps. Kapitonich enters the carriage. Vronsky hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Serozha all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, is that all I get? Yes, he's quite well. Vronsky steps forward. Anna knows he's there. She angles herself to avoid looking at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you have a good night? He bows to Karenin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, quite comfortable. Count Vronsky. Karenin extends a hand indifferently then dismisses Vronsky, drawing Anna with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to get back to the Committee . . . He walks Anna away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well--were you a success?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ? Oh--Dolly and Stiva . . . yes, I think so . . . Vronsky watches them go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S APARTMENT, ST. PETERSBURG-- DAY A snowy St. Petersburg street. Vronsky arrives home by cab. He has a flat in an old apartment block.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG, SAME TIME--DAY Vronsky rings the doorbell. A Servant opens the door. A male voice shouts "If it's someone demanding money, don't let him in!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll announce myself. Veronsky enters the main room. The occupant of the flat is a 2nd Lieuten- ant, Petritsky, wearing his greatcoat over shirt and trousers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky! The master himself. Baroness, coffee from the new coffeepot for Count Vronsky. Petritsky indicates a pretty young woman in satin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you are pleased by this ornament to your quarters. Vronsky bows and kisses her fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be off home if I'm in the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're at home where you are, Baroness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah!--Pierre, you never say such pretty things to me. We were just discussing my husband. He won't divorce me, you see. And do you know why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because he likes eating off my family silver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to bring an action. Just because I'm supposed to be unfaithful, I don't see why I have to eat off Pierre's crockery. Look at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my crockery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How was Moscow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Provincial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SEROZHA'S BEDROOM, KARENIN HOUSE-- NIGHT Anna, her dress changed, lies on Serozha's bed, on her side, one arm under his bedclothes scratching his back gently. He lies quietly on his stomach, with his eyes closed, his face inches from hers. In the dim light of a night- light she gazes at him for long moments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've stopped. She resumes scratching. He grunts contentedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for my present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sssh . . . She kisses him and continues to lie there, gently scratching. He falls quickly asleep. She removes her arm and restores his bedclothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a suite of rooms: the Bedroom connects to Anna's Boudoir/Dressing Room; and thence to Karenin's small Sitting Room/Dressing Room, which connects to the rest of the house. The rooms--like the whole house-- are lit by gas lamps but also by candles at key points.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KARENIN'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME-- NIGHT Korney, the Valet, gathers up a discarded shirt, etc. Karenin in a dressing gown is reading in a comfortable chair, by a candle lamp. Korney leaves.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: KARENIN'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME-- NIGHT
result.heading: KARENIN'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME-- NIGHT

direction.raw_text: Anna is at her bureau. She frowns and tears up the letter she is writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin looks at the clock-- nearly midnight-- and closes his book. He blows out the candle. He comes to the boudoir announcing himself with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Time for bed!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin comes to put his hand on Anna's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm writing to Dolly . . . and to Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are . . . good. Anna shakes her head and clasps his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, SAME TIME--NIGHT Candles each side of the bed. Karenin cracks his knuckles. He unlocks a drawer and opens a tin box lying in the drawer. Anna, disrobing, registers these sounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are they saying in Moscow about the new Statute?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What new Statute? Karenin takes a contraceptive sheath, made from animal intestine (re- usable) from the tin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The new Statute I carried in Council. Anna blows her candle out and gets into bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one mentioned it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah. Really? He comes to bed in his nightshirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here it made quite a sensation. He gets into bed. Anna waits dead-eyed. Karenin blows his candle out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KITTY'S ROOM, SHCHERBATSKY HOUSE, MOSCOW--DAY Kitty, a hollow-eyed version of herself, in a demure nightdress, sits upright on a chaise longue with her legs stretched out. The Family Doctor deferen- tially removes one of her slippers as though it were an intimate garment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me, Princess, but I must . . . With a silver "fork" the Doctor tests the sole of her foot for a reflex. Kitty is miserably going along with a farce she despises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Prince and Princess are hovering. The Princess flutters with anxiety, the Prince is in a temper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I the only one who knows what's wrong with her? But a Celebrity Doctor, as shiny as his own gold watch which he is check- ing, is bearing down on them, riding over a Footman's attempt to announce him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank God, doctor--my friends say you're the only one who can save her!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Possibly, Princess, possibly! At your service, Your Excellencies. Where is the patient?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KITTY'S ROOM, SAME TIME--DAY Kitty is sobbing with shame: the Celebrity Doctor has stripped her to the waist and is tapping her chest. The Family Doctor can't bear it and excuses himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, come, Princess, we are not backward people--I handle naked bodies every day. Deep breath now . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Family Doctor and the parents are in a huddle. The Prince is apoplectic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By God. I'll challenge the scoundrel!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the modern way . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the Prince) You're not a doctor!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her symptoms . . . loss of appetite, fast
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, whose pulse wouldn't be fast if some brute of a-- The Celebrity Doctor comes briskly out of Kitty's room, checking his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nervous palpitations. We must treat the nerves. A tubercular cavity is suspected, too soon to tell. Soden water every two hours. I must see her again tomorrow. (HE BOWS) Prince! Princess! He's gone. The Prince enters Kitty's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty is humiliated and triple-wrapped against the violation of her bosom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you fret, my little Kate! You'll wake up one fine morning and say to yourself--"I feel well and happy and I'll go out for a walk with Papa!" The Prince is mortified when Kitty's sobs redouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--DAY The social set Anna now moves in is the brilliant circle with connections to the Court on one hand and to the demi-monde of artists on the other. A leading light of this set is Princess Betsy Tverskaya, a rich society beauty. Betsy's immediate circle includes Tuskevich, her "admirer." Anna lifts her eyes to see Vronsky in front of her, talking to Betsy. Vronsky sees Anna and bows. She acknowledges him and kisses Betsy, and moves on, studying the next picture. Vronsky watches Anna move on. Betsy cocks an eye at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PIANO RECITAL, ST. PETERSBURG--DAY A few rows of chairs in someone's reception room, a mixed audience of guests, a flashy pianist . . . Betsy with a "toy" dog on her lap, Tuskevich on one side, Anna on the other. The dog yaps and sneezes. Betsy hands the dog to Tuskevich, who goes to exit with the dog. As Tuskevich leaves, Vronsky comes in. Anna sees him. She turns back to the piano. Betsy glances at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--DAY Anna and Betsy, on a bright snow-white day, are being driven through a park in Betsy's smart equipage . . . towards a horseman walking towards them: Vronsky salutes the little carriage as it trots by him. Anna keeps looking straight ahead. Betsy acknowledges Vronsky's salute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to give a small dinner before the opera. Is there anyone you would like me to ask?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes . . . Yes, the Metropolitan Bishop of St. Petersburg. Betsy laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annushka puts Anna's opera cloak over her shoulders, while Korney stands ready with Karenin's cloak and opera hat. Karenin comes down the stairs to join Anna. Kapitonich stands ready to let them out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess Lydia tells me you haven't been to one of her evenings since you returned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last one was to meet a missionary, the one before was for a lecture on the union of the Greek and Roman churches. (CLIMBS DOWN) I'm sorry--I know you're fond of her. Come on, or we'll be late. Kapitonich opens the door to let them out.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: STAIRS AND ENTRANCE HALL, KARENIN HOUSE--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT This is a small theatre with a "promenade" area where a group of Guards Officers of high and low rank mix together to enjoy the chanteuses, the comedians and the can-can girls. Vronsky is with his Commanding Officer, Colonel Demin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's the thing, Vronsky. A posting has come up and there's a promotion in it for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The garrison in Tashkent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tashkent? But . . . I would like to stay in Peter, sir, if you don't mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mind. But your mother . . . The can-can music starts up, to many cheers. Demin claps enthusiastically. Vronsky is angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT An attendant takes Vronsky's coat and gives him a token for it. There is a performance going on within, resolving into applause as he mounts the stairs. Karenin, an escapee looking at his pocket watch, comes down the stairs, goes down past Vronsky, looks back at him for a moment, and continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky enters the box as the performance prepares to resume. It is the Tverskoy box, occupied by Princess Betsy and her husband, who is likeable, overweight and, strangely enough, looking at an antiquarian book; wear- ing white gloves. Vronsky bows to them and sits down next to Betsy. He takes her opera glasses and looks through them at the Karenin box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't come to my dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had to see my Commanding Officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "She" didn't come either. Vronsky watches Anna through the glasses. Countess Lydia Ivanovna is next to her. Lydia is in her forties, sallow, no beauty, sincerely religious, and determined.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . work never ceases for great men. Your husband is a saint and we must all cherish him for Russia's sake. Anna winces a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you can come on afterwards--Father Kristof's report on the Chinese mission will be with lantern slides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm expected at the Tverskoys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No doubt, but I'm sure Princess Betsy can wait for you, my dear. Anna glances at Betsy's box and sees Vronsky there. The opera resumes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. In fact, I think I won't go to Betsy's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TVERSKOY OPERA BOX, SAME TIME--NIGHT Vronsky looks through Betsy's glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're caught.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid I am becoming ridiculous.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: KARENIN OPERA BOX, SAME TIME--NIGHT LYDIA

direction.raw_text: Discreet Footmen move chairs to accommodate the guests who move to join one of the conversation circles that make a buzz in the room. Betsy sits by the samovar with her little court, including Tuskevich. The Guests include the Princess Myagkaya, stout, red-faced, outspoken, and two Society ladies, Lisa Merkalova and "Anna's Friend." Vronsky arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, there's a phenomenon, look-- Anna's shadow has arrived before Anna! ANNA'S FRIEND I'm Anna's friend . . . but this making-up- one's-mind-to-it in public is not polite to a distinguished man like Karenin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In my opinion Karenin is a fool, and Anna is the best of us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we all love you for your contrary opin- ions, Princess. Vronsky looks around. He knows everybody in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei . . . You look desperate. That's not attractive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm losing hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hope of what? Persuading a virtuous woman to break her marriage vows?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how is Tuskevich?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not attractive either. Besides, I was never virtuous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No--you're right. She won't come. I'm going home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT The Karenin coach arrives. It's Anna arriving at Betsy's. She enters the house in almost unseemly haste. Several coaches are waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAB, ST. PETERSBURG, SAME TIME--NIGHT Vronsky, in a state, lets himself be carried along. Then he changes his mind. He puts his head out of the window to shout to the Coachman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn round!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna enters. Faces turn to her. She glances around. She knows at once that Vronsky isn't there. Betsy beckons to her across the room. Anna, self- possessed, smiling, nodding to friends, pressing a hand held out to her, offering the other hand to be kissed, glides through a crowd of Betsy's guests.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wasn't Nilsson glorious? One sees that she has studied Kaulbach, of course . . . There's something Louis Quinze about Tuskevich . . . as if he came with the furniture . . . Betsy is smoking elegantly. She kisses Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's gone. But you're just in time for the surprise. There is a series of minor explosions outside and the darkness out there turns into an illuminated garden lit by fountains of fire, sprays of light. The guests react with cries of pleasure and applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna turns at once to the window near her, puts her face up against the glass, putting her hands to her temples as if to see the illuminations better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her self-possessed face, lit by fireworks, falls apart in misery. The firework display continues for a short minute and is applauded. Betsy acknowledges the congratulations and sycophancy which are her due. Foot- men come through the room with trays of ices. Anna is still at the window, unaware that there is only darkness outside. In the room, Betsy notes the oddity: Anna alone with her back to the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna opens her eyes. She is lost for a moment, perplexed. vronsky (O.C.) May I have the honour of bringing you an ice? Anna turns, understanding nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ices are being served.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would prefer to try a cigarette. She sits down. Vronsky takes out a cigarette case. He lights her cigarette. She tries it and coughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Courage! Anna smiles. Puffs delicately once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. She gives the cigarette to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll try another one sometime.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When? She looks at him in surprise. He dunks the cigarette in an abandoned dish of ice cream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just as I was thinking your manners have improved since Moscow. You behaved badly, very badly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And who was responsible for that? Anna gets up and walks over to Betsy's chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a cup of tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betsy obediently gets up to fill a cup from the samovar. Vronsky follows Anna. This is watched by more than one guest. Betsy hands the cup to Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How nice--Alexei Aleksandrevich has arrived. Karenin enters smiling. Lisa Merkalova and Anna's Friend share a delicious-malicious moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure my nerves can stand another Alexei at this moment. As Betsy and Karenin move smilingly to greet each other, Karenin's radar picks up the two women's intimate laughter. Karenin remains at apparent ease, as though unaware of people's glances at Vronsky and Anna, and he kisses Betsy's hand. Princess Myagkaya has meanwhile gone over to Anna. Anna likes her and is glad of the diversion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So the Schuzburgs asked us to dinner. The sauce was said to have cost a thousand rou- bles, and it was ghastly. We had to ask them back. I gave them a sauce that cost eighty- five kopeks and it was a triumph. Anna and Vronsky laugh. Princess Myagkaya moves on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you glad to see me or not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This must stop. You make me feel as if I were guilty of something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want me to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to go to Moscow and beg Kitty to forgive you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, that's not what you want. Moscow? I can do better than that. Tonight I refused a posting to Tashkent. I can change my mind, and you'll never see me again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you have any thought for me, you will give me back my peace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no peace to give. There can be no peace for us--only misery or the greatest happiness. You are my whole life now. She looks at him and nods slowly, as if in thought. Betsy diplomatically leads Karenin to Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your husband is impossible!-- his opinions are all wrong but he talks so brilliantly he wins every argument. Anna looks up at her, hearing nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? She notices Karenin, who kisses her hand. Vronsky acknowledges Karenin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I called to take you home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm staying. Send the carriage back for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. He bows to Betsy. Ignoring Vronsky, he turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky is with one group of guests, Anna with another. She is animated, excited, at a small table, involved in a game of cards-- which she wins, to local applause. She speaks a "must go" to Betsy, and swiftly goes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dressed for outdoors, Anna comes down the staircase. The Doorkeeper sees her, opens the door and signals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Karenin coach moves to the entrance door, which is held open by the Doorkeeper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TVERSKOY HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT Anna hears hurried footsteps on the stairs. She hesitates. She continues towards the door. Vronsky catches up with her. The Doorkeeper holds the door open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want me to go to Tashkent?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG, SAME TIME--NIGHT The two horses are restless in the freezing air. Konrad looks to the open door. Nobody coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG, SAME TIME--NIGHT VRONSKY So I'll go to Tashkent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I don't want you to go. She turns and goes out. Vronsky follows her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG, SAME TIME--NIGHT Vronsky opens the carriage door for her. She gets into the coach, he closes the door. He watches the coach go. His face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KARENIN COACH, SAME TIME--NIGHT Her face.
direction.name: direction
