direction.raw_text: Kapitonich lets Anna in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin, reading by candlelight in his dressing gown, hears the sounds of Anna's return, all the way to her entrance. He cracks his knuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waiting up? How unlike you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I stayed up to talk to you. Anna keeps going, to her dressing room/boudoir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about? It's late. Where's Annushka? He waits for her to return without her cloak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sent her off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if you want to talk, but we should go to bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to warn you about something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warn me? It's really rather late . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish to warn you that you may inadver- tently, by indiscretion and carelessness, give the world occasion to talk about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not a committee. Please say what you want to tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You and Count Vronsky attracted attention tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't like it when I don't talk to people, and you don't like it when I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't notice anything, myself. But I saw that everyone else noticed. I consider jeal- ousy to be insulting to you and degrading to me. I have no right to inquire into your feelings. They concern only your conscience. But I'm your husband and I love you. It's my duty to remind you that we are bound together by God, and this bond can only be broken by a crime against God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have nothing to say to you, and I'm tired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you have a son. She returns to the boudoir. After a moment he follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin finds her in her underwear, throwing aside her dress. He apolo- gises for that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me. (TURNING ASIDE) If I am wrong, I ask your pardon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you're talking about, and it's really too late for this. Excuse me, please. Because she wants to undress, Karenin leaves her.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: ANNA'S BOUDOIR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: Anna lies in bed next to Karenin, elated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the next instant, seemingly in her own bed, she gasps and jerks as though her body has taken a blow. The CUTS are now between a fragmented narrative of voracious sex ("SEX AS BEFORE") and "prelude to sex," this being a sequence of shots starting with:--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY APARTMENT, DAY Anna arrives, heavily veiled, by cab. She enters the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY APARTMENT, SAME TIME--DAY Vronsky opens his door to Anna. They don't speak. He takes her hand and brings her in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S APARTMENT, SAME TIME--DAY Vronsky leads Anna through the apartment to the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S BEDROOM, SAME TIME--DAY Vronsky takes off Anna's outer clothes, slowly and carefully, starting with her hat and veil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S BEDROOM, SAME TIME--DAY Anna, in underclothes, unbuttons Vronsky's shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S BEDROOM, SAME TIME--DAY Anna and Vronsky are standing kissing passionately. He has no shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S BEDROOM, SAME TIME--DAY Anna ends up half off the edge of Vronsky's bed, climaxing upside down and falling to the floor. Vronsky, also half off the bed, looks down at her. He reaches down for her. She grasps hold of his hand, huddled, hugs it to her, distressed to tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh God forgive me. It's the end of everything--I've got nothing left now, only you. Remember that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna . . . Anna . . . how can I not remem- ber? You're my happiness. He draws her back on to the bed, kisses her face, her shoulder . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happiness! You murdered my happiness. She tries to leave but he attacks her as a lover, and she gives way, responding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murderer. Murderer. Go on. Go on. Go on. She starts hitting him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Go on. Go on. Go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In sunshine, a large chunk of ice loses its purchase on winter and goes floating along a stream of tiny ice floes between grassy banks almost free of snow, with early aconites showing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The icy stream flows under a footbridge which has a broken handrail. Vasili, the steward, is on the bridge with a Carpenter. Levin, on horseback, is displeased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought that had been done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gave the order. What can you do with these people? Levin rides on, into an expanded prospect of fields and woods, snow on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When Levin gets in view of the house, he is puzzled by the distant sight of a three-horse sledge arriving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The new arrival is Oblonsky, enjoying his food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah--potage aux choux a la Russe! Agafia comes in with the roast fowl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Agafia!--if you opened up in Moscow, l'Angleterre would go out of business. Do you want news of Moscow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of Babylon? No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right, what do you care? You love the country--you've got it. You love agricultur- ing, and, Lord knows, you've got it. You love shooting--you've got it. You've got every- thing you want! Agafia, leaving, throws Levin a look (no wife).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, go on, then. Have you stopped stealing bread rolls?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ballet girl, oriental type. How can I help it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, nothing new to tell me. How is--how are the Shcherbatskys?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . Is she engaged now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Vronsky went back to St. Petersburg. He waits for this to sink in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty will be at Ergoshovo visiting Dolly in the summer. You could . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes, as if I had time in the summer! And I've got extra land this year at Kashin for the haymaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kashin? That's on the Ergoshovo road, isn't it? Won't you call when Kitty is there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Especially not then. I humiliated myself once. Now it's a row.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn you, Kostya, you love Kitty and you can't forgive her because, first, you funked it, then you bungled it, then you ran away from an eighteen-year-old girl who was made a fool of by a uniform. It's Kitty I'm sorry for--not you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her heart told her no. Did you come to shoot snipe or criticize me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin and Oblonsky, with Laska, wait with their guns, a few yards apart. Levin has calmed down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For you, getting married is . . . a social engage- ment. Not for me. For me, it's the condition of personal happiness and living the right way. I'll never again be carried away by passion. I renounce it. I'll have to find another way . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look out--here they come! A couple of snipe come drumming over the trees. The men fire simultane- ously. One snipe falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bad luck! Oblonsky laughs. Despite himself, Levin laughs too. Laska retrieves the bird.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY NURSERY, OBLONSKY HOUSE--DAY SPRING Dolly has had her baby. She is holding the infant, having just finished feeding him. Kitty is with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There. Oh, I'm sore with his feeding! Would you like to hold him? Dolly gives the baby to Kitty, who takes him almost unwillingly. Dolly buttons herself. Kitty's maternal instinct won't engage. Dolly notes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, don't hold him like a parcel . . . It's Aunt Kitty, darling. . . . Little face . . . little fingers . . . look at you . . . Doesn't he make you ashamed of dwelling on your troubles . . . ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no troubles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That man wasn't worth the tears, believe me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care about him. I don't even think about him. Or her. Except to hate her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we'll never speak of it again. Dolly relieves Kitty of the baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are better men waiting for you. Stiva says . . . Kitty, my lamb, did Konstantin Levin . . . ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What has Levin got to do with it? Anyway, I'll never get married. The whole business of . . . it's become disgusting to me . . . and look what it's done for you! Why do they call it love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because it's love. Lovingly, she settles the baby in his crib, her face filled with tender joy at the bargain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . IDYLLIC COUNTRYSIDE--DAY SPRING A lovers' idyll, by a stream on a warm day. Anna, lightly dressed, smoking a cigarette, watches Vronsky fill his wineglass from a tethered bottle in the stream. There is a pony trap which brought them. He comes back to sit by her. She kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to. I don't care about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should care. You're not supposed to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pooh! Who says?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody. Doctors. She laughs and throws her cigarette into the stream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're squeamish. You a soldier! Would you faint?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway, someone might be watching. Anna looks all around. Vast emptiness. She lifts a dock leaf to look under it. She looks up at the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I'm damned anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not. I'm blessed. Anna pushes him onto his back and straddles him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You love me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Apart from Frou-Frou.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Anna holds his face between her hands and works her body on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But me more than your horse?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you happy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you love me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This much. Anna drags the front of her skirts out of her way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This much? And this much? And this much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And . . . this . . . much . . . ? She falls on him. He strokes her hair. Her hand comes into view, the index finger bloody. She carefully paints his lips with it. She kisses his lips clean, and rolls off him onto her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So this is love. This.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KARENIN'S STUDY, KARENIN HOUSE--DAY SUMMER Korney brings Countess Lydia. Karenin comes from behind his desk to invite her to a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess . . . I thought you would be at Peterhof now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've come from there. I'm distressed that you haven't taken your usual house this year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna wanted a change. She is spending the summer at Tsarskoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Near Princess Betsy. And . . . Karenin waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Guards are in summer camp at Tsarskoe. Karenin waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei Alexandrovich, forgive me but you are too tolerant! Your wife . . . Karenin affects surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, is this about my wife? He smiles at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My wife is beyond reproach. She is, after all, my wife. Countess Lydia gets the message. She rises to go. Karenin kisses her hand and accompanies her to the door. She leaves him, and his social mask gives way to his disturbance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Commanding Officer is throwing a party for his officers: serious drink- ing, Soldier Servants, a crowded table on the large verandah, Soldier Sing- ers in white linen tunics performing operetta and folk songs. Vronsky, in party spirit, is with Petritsky and another friend, Yashvin, singing along. An officer we don't know is, surprisingly, hailed as "Vronsky!"--he's Vronsky's elder brother, Alexander. He gestures "Later!" and goes to Vron- sky. The brothers embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alyosha . . . a message from Maman. Her friend Princess Sorokina has a house here, and a virgin daughter, that's not part of the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: message, but they'll all be at the races and you're expected to supper afterwards. The song ends and Demin, half drunk, climbs on the table, shouts for silence and a toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen--I give you--the regiment! General uproar. "The regiment."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On a garden bench where the noise of the party is quieter, Vronsky and Alexander talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard you turned down a promotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was Maman interfering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. And now she's come up with a princess for you. (SERIOUSLY) Alexei--we're brothers, so don't take offence. Getting married puts the pack on your back--it leaves your hands free for climbing the ladder. Getting serious about a married woman is like carrying your pack in your arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So they talk about me. I'm leaving, Sasha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An assignation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, I'll introduce you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky with Alexander beside him clucks his tongue at the black opening of a stable and calls softly for Frou-Frou. There's a stir within and the mare's head appears. Vronsky opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beautiful. A man would come to no harm. Do you think you'll win tomorrow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Makhotin's Gladiator is favourite, sixteen hands--Frou-Frou looks dainty beside him, but she's got heart. Haven't you, my darling? He kisses Frou-Frou.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky sees Anna before she sees him. He pauses to look at her, struck by her beauty, full of love for her. She is lost in thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna. She has not been expecting him. She is concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei, what is it? He shakes his head: nothing. She comes to him and hides her face in his breast. He holds her tight, taking her hand and kissing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't bear not to see you before the race. She hugs him, kissing his tunic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What were you thinking about? She continues to hide her face. He lifts her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm pregnant. Vronsky presses her hand to his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah . . . My love. He kisses her brow and her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, love was never a game to us. Here's an end to living in corners, existing day to day on lies. Yes, now we can be together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can we, Alexei?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Karenin everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think my husband will make you a present of me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave him and be your mistress?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Run away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would never see my son again. The laws are made by husbands and fathers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, then? I'll never forgive myself for your unhappiness. Anna looks into his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unhappiness? I'm like a starving beggar who has been given food. She smiles rapturously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I unhappy? No, this is my happiness! She kisses him deeply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a good maze. Anna and Serozha are running, laughing, between the hedges. It's a game. She is trying to find her way to him, chasing him. A hedge divides them. Serozha darts away from her, runs into a dead end, doubles back. She spots him, follows him, and now he has eluded her again. Serozha finds his way out of the maze and is confronted by Karenin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you, young man? Your tutor doesn't seem to be in evidence. We'll have a look at your lesson books. Anna, coming out of the maze, sees Karenin, recovers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei!--you got away at last. Can you stay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why . . . ? Serozha looks scared to tears. Anna kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go and find Vasily Lukich. Serozha runs into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to change. Princess Betsy is sending her trap for me. Would you like to come?-- she's taking me to watch the race. Karenin smiles coldly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Races, surely. No, I'll come on later, and then I must get back to town. Anna returns to the house. She wipes her kissed hand on her skirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a rough-and-ready racecourse but the venue for a high society occa- sion, with a grandstand for top people and a grander section, ornamented for greater comfort, for members of the Imperial family. It is also a fashion parade for some. The racecourse itself is an oval approached by a straight. There are nine fences, water-jumps, etc., of various difficulty. The "jockeys" are officers in the Guards, the Hussars and other regiments. Among them is Vronsky, attended by a Trainer who is fussing over Frou- Frou's bridle and calming her. Vronsky looks with interest at a big power- ful horse which must be Gladiator, with Captain Makhotin already in the saddle. Makhotin and Vronsky greet each other with a nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: arrives at the races . . . making his way towards the front, smiling, raising his hat to acquaintances . . . his eyes busy looking for his wife. He reaches the front and looks up at the Ladies' Stand.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: THE LADIES' STAND, THE RACES, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: THE LADIES' STAND, THE RACES, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . THE LADIES' STAND, THE RACES, SAME TIME-- DAY Anna and Betsy are here, and, not far away, so are Countess Vronsky and the Princesses Sorokina: the mother is a fading fortyish; the daughter is eighteen, blonde and pretty. Below the ladies section is a planked standing area for gentlemen, who also may stand to watch the races from the stepped aisle of the seated section. Soldiers, Horse People and Locals watch from the turf. A race is flowing towards the winning post, with accompanying crowd reac- tion, but it is clear from Anna's detachment, exchanging chat with Betsy, that this is not Vronsky's race.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --looks up to the ladies' stand. Betsy smiles at him in greeting, but Anna seems unaware. Countess Vronsky appraises the young princess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exquisite creature . . . you really ought to be the spoil of victory today . . . The young princess smiles at her. Countess Vronsky turns her glasses towards the Starting Post.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEAR THE STARTING POST, THE RACES, SAME TIME--DAY . . . Vronsky mounts Frou-Frou. The Riders move to the starting line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . watches Anna who is looking through her glasses towards the Starting Post while the current race finishes to cheers.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: NEAR THE STARTING POST, THE RACES, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: :-- Anna's anxious attention turns to a horse and rider who fell further down the course-- and to the ambulance wagon (with a red cross sewn on it) . . . Karenin mounts the steps of the aisle, raising his hat to ladies he knows. Anna ignores him. On the wooden boards below, where gentlemen are watching, Oblonsky calls up to Betsy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Princess! A bet! What do you fancy in the next?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kusolev.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm on Vronsky. A pair of gloves?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Done! (TO ANNA) Alexander Vronsky . . . In the aisle at the top of the stand, Karenin watches as:-- Vronsky's brother Alexander, escorting his wife, Varya, bows to Anna and Betsy, but significantly Varya succeeds in not noticing them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The riders line up . . . and they're off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stands and spectators are distant, the first fence coming at him, horses on either side. His neighbour falls at the fence but Frou-Frou is clear, with Gladiator half a length in front. The next fence is coming up. Gladiator and Frou-Frou jump cleanly but a following horse falls badly.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: STARTING POST, THE RACES, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: Spectators on either side of Anna and those behind and in front collectively react.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: LADIES' STAND, THE RACES, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: : Anna reacts not at all. Her gaze through her glasses stays unwavering on Vronsky. Karenin notes this, and from then on his attention is fixed on Anna. When the horses come opposite the stand, she lowers her glasses and follows Frou-Frou taking the lead from Gladiator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: eases Frou-Frou past Gladiator. The horses take the next jump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With one hand Anna grips her folded fan. Karenin's face is a mask as he watches Anna unconsciously half-destroying it. She raises her glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THROUGH GLASSES Frou-Frou approaches the last fence with Gladiator half a length behind, on the near side to Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: working the reins, rising and falling in rhythm with the horse, looks ahead to the winning post, and before knowing it he makes an error, losing the rhythm, dropping back into the saddle and raising the horse's head, just as Frou-Frou takes off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frou-Frou rises, Gladiator rises. Frou-Frou disappears. Gladiator clears the fence in Anna's foreground. Simultaneously, there are shrieks and exclamations all around her-- OFF CAMERA-- and the view through the glasses zigzags in search of Frou-Frou, impeded by horses jumping the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lowers the glasses and sees Frou-Frou on the ground, rolling over, and Vronsky on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sees this, too, her mouth set tight with contempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --looks shocked. Almost in the same moment he hears Anna's anguished cry, conspicuous in the hubbub that follows the crowd's exclamation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei . . . !
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here. This is adroit. He comes down several steps and pushes through to offer his arm, but Anna has lost control, trying to escape like a bird beating against its cage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like to leave? Anna ignores him, puts her glasses to her eyes, searching out Vronsky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky extricates himself from his broken horse and, in terrible recrimina- tion, tries to pull Frou-Frou to her feet by the reins. Frou-Frou struggles to get up but her back is broken. Officials, officers, and a doctor have come running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . sees an Officer hurrying to the Imperial party to report.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stiva! What are they saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky's unhurt--but the horse . . . Anna relapses into sobs, attempting to hide her face behind her destroyed fan. Betsy gives Anna her fan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --is restrained by an Officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her back's broken! The Officer takes a pistol from his holster. Vronsky, enraged and in grief, takes the pistol from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --persists with Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm asking you . . . if you wish to go . . . He touches Anna's arm. She jerks it away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, leave me alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll bring her home, Alexei.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, Princess, but Anna is not well and I want her to come with me. A gunshot is heard from the course. Anna turns her tear-streaked face towards it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOVING COACH--DAY Anna's hysteria has solidified into a blank despair. Karenin seems to want to pretend that nothing important has happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know . . . they say the Emperor dis- approves of the races . . . the danger of injury . . . but I . . . Anna looks at him contemptuously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm saying there is a value in manly sport, for the military--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In my opinion, it's not the sport itself that's wrong, it's the spectacle, it's making a cruel spectacle out of--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about? Karenin changes tack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to tell you--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to tell you, you behaved improperly today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how was that? She has raised her voice. He raises a warning finger, and reaches to close the communication window behind the coachman's box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By making plain your feelings when one of the riders fell. Your conduct was improper. It must not occur again. I have said it before. Anna smiles faintly. He is misled by that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are going to say my concern is unneces- sary and ridiculous. You are my wife. I am wrong to think that . . . yes--perhaps I was mistaken. Anna looks at him despairingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you were not mistaken. I love him. I am his mistress. I can't bear you, I'm afraid of you, I hate you. Do what you like to me. Karenin is literally winded--gasping for breath, slowly getting his breath- ing under control. Anna huddles away from him in her corner. Karenin recovers himself only to the point of sitting stock-still, looking at nothing, not moving. The coach lurches, unbalancing him so that he is pushed against Anna. He recoils as if from a contamination. The coach slows. The coach stops. A Servant comes to the coach door, opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, please. Move away. The Servant backs off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will not have a scandal. Therefore . . . You will not see . . . this man again. You will behave in such a way that nothing is known against you, by society or by the servants. In return, you will keep the privileges of a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wife--and the duties. Tomorrow you will return home. That is all. Anna gets out of the coach and runs into the maze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna comes to Vronsky. She is still shaken by the showdown with Karenin in his coach, but is now overtaken by concern for Vronsky after his fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you hurt? Vronsky shakes his head. He is moved by the sight of her, full of love and desire, but in her embrace he detects something new, a nervous exaltation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told him I'm your mistress. Vronsky lifts her face, strokes her cheek. He waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thinks I can give you up and go on living. He embraces her for that, relieved, grateful, loving--understanding that she is not going to give him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you cannot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (ST. PETERSBURG)--NIGHT Imperial hands (the Tsar's for all we know) place over Karenin's head a broad red ribbon from which hangs a heavy medal. Karenin bows low.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT At an ornate doorway a Major-Domo announces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their Excellencies Minister Karenin and Madame Karenin! Karenin, wearing his medal, and Anna smile their way into a party, to a patter of polite applause. Further grandees are being announced, but are not applauded . . . Prince and Princess Berghatskoy . . . Ambassador Chamber- lain . . . Baron and Baroness Verdlov . . . Prince and Princess Tverskoy . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei Aleksandrevich . . . congratulations. You're the only man my husband would do this for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (To Prince Tverskoy) Tell me your latest find for your library.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not in front of the Princess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betsy draws Anna away for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can tell you're happy. You've put on a little weight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SEROZHA'S BEDROOM, KARENIN'S HOUSE-- NIGHT Anna, in the same dress, kisses Serozha tenderly so as not to wake him, and leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna enters the suite where Karenin, in his dressing gown, puts down his book. He is elated by his evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Time for bed!
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: BEDROOM LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG-- NIGHT Anna is in bed. Karenin is getting ready for bed. Anna listens apprehen- sively to the little noises of Karenin's pre-coital preparations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . not that I care for decorations but . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei . . . I can't . . . I'm sorry . . . But I'm his wife now. (she turns to him) I am having his child. Karenin stares at her. He turns back to the open drawer and puts things back the way they were. He locks the drawer. He puts on his dressing gown and leaves the room. Anna waits a moment and follows him.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: SITTING ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- NIGHT
result.heading: SITTING ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . SITTING ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- NIGHT It's dark. Anna hears the crack of his knuckles and can see him faintly, sitting in the dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me what I did to deserve this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A prospect: next to a country road, a large expanse of meadow is being mown forty swathes at a time by forty mowers swinging their scythes almost in unison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R--Levin is suffering but keeping up, bathed in perspiration. His place is behind an old man, Theodore, who is scything as if without effort. Just in time for Levin, Theodore calls a halt and takes Levin's scythe to sharpen it with a whetstone. Levin attracts a few grins and comments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Konstantin Dmitrich, you'll know your rows when the field's all done! Levin's row has stalks of differing heights between the even swathes on either side. There is some laughter, but the men are uneasy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's time to stop for the day. More tomorrow. The Mowers with their scythes walk back across the large meadow of cut swathes. From the other direc- tion, a crowd of Village Women are coming to meet them carrying food and drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fire has been lit. The Mowers eat their meal in the company of women. Serafina tends to a cooking pot in the firelight. Levin watches her discreetly. He has settled down at a discreet distance from the men. His attention is caught by a grown-up Boy and his young Wife who have chosen to sit slightly apart. He is charmed by them, watching the girl serve her husband. Theodore comes to Levin with a jug. Levin takes a swig.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many mowers is it, Theodore?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forty-two, master. In your father's time it was work for two days for thirty men . . . (SLYLY) . . . though he never picked up a scythe himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men don't like me for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They like what they're used to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It settles me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is that, master?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I'm mowing, I don't ask myself why I'm here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're here to be master, Konstantin Dmi- trich, to be your father's son, and father to a son who will be master after you, as it has always been by the grace of God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father owned you, Theodore. My grand- father owned your father. Owned you like chattels, to be bought and sold. Was that by the grace of God?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was. Those were good times when your father had the keeping of us. That's my youngest you were looking at there. His young life is perilous now since the Free- dom came and work must be found.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's true I was looking at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At his wife too, I dare say. Levin is abashed, found out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look happier than I've ever been. Is it living simply that I'm looking for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Night under the stars. Some of the men have gone, some have settled in for the night. The cooking fire is burning out. Levin remains where he was, watching, thinking: drawn to "the simple life."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin wakes . . . woken by hoofbeats and the jingle of harness. Levin sees a coach coming towards him. The coach comes nearer, leather boxes strapped to the roof. Levin sees that a young woman is looking out of the side window, holding on to the white ribbons of her bonnet. He sees that it is Kitty, on her way to Ergoshovo. (Princess Shcherbatsky is also inside, dozing.) The coach passes on, leaving Levin lovelorn, the dawn light on him. The sight of Kitty has turned him round again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STATION, ST PETERSBURG--DAY AUTUMN Vronsky stands at the entrance to the platform holding a bouquet, waiting for a train. He looks pretty fed up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT As before, the set-up is a small stage, a small auditorium, and an area for drinking, cruising, etc., a combination of music hall and a bar with a few tables. Vronsky is here as the escort of a Foreign Prince (an Indian), watch- ing a "risque" show with Can-Can Girls, much relished by the visitor. Vronsky's glance casts about in the gloom. The champagne is flowing. Vron- sky spots a trio--Lisa Merkalova, Betsy, and Stremov, a politician and Karenin's rival. Vronsky catches Betsy's eye. She beckons him. He excuses himself to the Foreign Prince, who doesn't notice, and goes over to the other table. Under the music, he is introduced to Stremov, and kisses the hands of the women. He takes the empty chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's some kind of prince at home. Exhaust- ing. Where is Tuskevitch this evening?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why ask me? At which moment, Makhotin appears at the table. Vronsky relinquishes his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Captain Makhotin . . . Vronsky bows to the women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must leave you. I'm on duty tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucky woman. Give her my respects, and to Karenin if you see him. Vronsky freezes in anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't. Would you compromise me? And Lisa? Lisa and Stremov are enjoying it. Vronsky turns away. The Foreign Prince is applauding enthusiastically when Vronsky rejoins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I only say that a man who can't govern his wife has perhaps gone as far as he can go in government.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG-- DAY Vronsky wakes. He has fallen asleep in his clothes. A note has been deliv- ered, propped up by the bed. He reaches for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KARENIN HOUSE, ST. PETERSBURG--NIGHT A cab brings Vronsky. The Karenin coach is waiting outside. As Vronsky approaches the door, it opens and Kapitonich comes out with a folded rug. Kapitonich is wrong-footed by seeing him. Karenin comes out of the door, into the gaslight. When he sees Vronsky he hesitates for a fraction but con- tinues. Kapitonich is holding open the door of the coach. Vronsky bows, Karenin, expressionless, touches his hat and gets into the coach, taking the rug. Vronsky walks into the house as the coach moves off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kapitonich comes in, closing the door. Vronsky gives him his hat and coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, Your Excellency. Kapitonich is uneasy. A Footman comes from a service door. He sees Vron- sky and looks to Kapitonich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am expected. Kapitonich nods to the Footman.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: ENTRANCE HALL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: Anna, six months pregnant, is seated almost formally. The Footman lets Vronsky in and retires closing the door. Anna runs to Vronsky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!--no. I will not live like this! He holds her, calming her, hushing her. He leads her into a Winter Garden conservatory off the Reception Room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waiting hour after hour while you're drink- ing champagne with naked actresses-- don't think I don't know!--Lisa Merkalova still calls on me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's punishment enough that I'm on escort duty, without . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes--I'm sorry--it's my demon, I can't help it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wrote that you were ill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did I? Well, I am! (GAILY) But don't worry! It won't be for long, I'll soon be out of your way--soon!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's true. I was told it in a dream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There, it was only a bad dream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, and I'm only going to die having your baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all nonsense! She kisses him all over his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me it is, tell me it is. You love me. Only me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your note said your husband would be out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was late. Serves him right. And you. Why do you call him my husband? He isn't my husband--he's a clock, a wooden doll--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it was awkward . . . a matter of your honour. You made an agreement. Anna flares up again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think of my honour when you're sharing whores with your Hindoo!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your demon again!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be glad to die, before you start to hate me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna . . . Anna gives a gasp. She laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put your hand there. There! Did you feel him move!
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: RECEPTION ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT "The Committee" is in session. Stremov has the floor. He is referring to a map of Russia on an easel, splotched with colours. Karenin is there but not listening, his thoughts far away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must respectfully ask Minister Karenin whether his proposals for the regulation of these colourful Gypsy tribes, of these schol- arly God-fearing Jews, and of--but I'm afraid I have lost the Minister's attention . . . All turn to look at Karenin, who sits staring at nothing, unaware even of the pause. He wakes. For a beat he hardly knows where he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kapitonich lets Karenin in. Karenin is brisk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only Madame, Your Excellency. Karenin goes up the staircase. There is an urgency in him, a fury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin walks in and goes to her bureau, empties out little drawers and receptacles, looking for the key to the main drawer. Anna comes in from the bedroom, alarmed, in her nightdress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to see him because . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not wish to be told why a woman wants to see her lover. He pulls furiously at the locked drawer, then looks around for an implement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you . . . ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want his letters. Karenin finds an iron bootjack. Anna tries to stop him. He pushes her aside and smashes the wood around the lock, then, struggling against her, he takes from the open drawer a pretty cardboard box, a good guess. He confirms that it contains letters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am going to Moscow tomorrow, and then to the provinces with a commission to investigate conditions among the Jews and Gypsies--whose conditions I infinitely prefer to my own. I will not return to this house until divorce has put you into the street. Meanwhile my son will be sent to live with my eldest sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei . . . please . . . leave me Serozha . . . ! Karenin looks at her with contempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think I would let you have my son? You are depraved, a woman without honour. I thank God the curse of love is lifted from me. He walks out with the box of letters.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: ANNA'S BOUDOIR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: Oblonsky arrives outside his office building in a cab. He enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Saluted by the Hall Porter, Oblonsky mounts a semi-grand staircase and arrives at the entrance to his department. He goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OUTER ROOM, OBLONSKY'S OFFICE, SAME TIME--DAY Levin stands up in his almost new, hardly used coat, top hat and boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin! What . . . ? Levin smiles, hopefully, sheepish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need your advice . . . It's a reprise. Oblonsky understands. He seizes Levin and kisses him.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: OUTER ROOM, OBLONSKY'S OFFICE, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: A small group. Dolly is playing the piano. Kitty turns the pages for Dolly. The old Prince Shcherbatsky and the Princess are with Countess Nordston and Oblonsky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, is he coming? Kitty, keeping half an eye on the door, sees Levin enter and misses the page- turn. Oblonsky goes to greet Levin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I late? Who is here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course you're late! Come and meet . . . Countess Nordston.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (drily, amused) We nearly met at the Shcherbatsky's last winter. Levin, puzzled, bows to her and to the Prince and Princess, who are respec- tively pleased and making the best of it, and then to Dolly who approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come into the fold . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty is here. Levin is shaken. Dolly leads him to Kitty, who is frightened, shy and shamefaced. Dolly leaves them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Konsantin . . . what a long time since we saw each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since you saw me, but I saw you not so long ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were driving to Ergoshovo . . . I was at Kashin for the haymaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but why didn't you . . . ? They are both embarrassed by the wrong step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so glad to see you. You're just the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope not--I was young and silly in those days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Months and months ago!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you haven't changed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I haven't. Kitty looks up at him, decoding. They gauge each other shyly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Permit me to announce--soup Marie Lou- ise, carp with asparagus, and roast beef! I went to the market in person! But Matvey at that moment presents Oblonsky with a visiting card on a salver. Oblonsky reads it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An extra place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The new arrival is Karenin. Oblonsky is pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin!--I'm glad you came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been on tour in the regions, a govern- ment commission . . . I'm sorry--I have come to tell you our connection must be severed. I'm going to divorce your sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Divorce? Dear me, what are you talking about? Don't be in a hurry. Stay to dinner and later talk it over with Dolly--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince Oblonsky, everything is over between our families.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei . . . divorce is one thing but dinner is quite another.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: ENTRANCE HALL, OBLONSKY HOUSE, SAME TIME--NIGHT

direction.raw_text: Dinner for eight-- clockwise, Oblonsky, Countess Nordston, Prince Shcher- batsky, Kitty, Karenin, Dolly, Levin and Princess Shcherbatsky. Two Servants and Matvey serve at the table, clearing away the "carp with asparagus." The Princess is challenging Karenin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You Petersburgers think yourselves so de bon ton compared with dull, old-fashioned
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moscow, but we know how to do things-- only the other day, I hear, Vasya Pryachnikov fought a duel with Kvitsky and killed him. Oblonskky attempts to divert the conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, what's this government commission, Karenin . . . ? But Karenin ignores him. Oblonsky looks on helplessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was the challenge about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pryachnikov's wife, naturally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was a matter of honour, defending a woman's honour . . . Karenin remains cool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sounds like barbarism to me . . . And what if the lover had killed the husband?-- would that have preserved the wife's honour too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still, not many of us can say that our lover died for love!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love? Thou shall not covet thy neighbour's wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you die for love, Konstantin Dmitrich?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would. But not for my neighbour's wife. Levin is nettled to find that he seems to have made a joke, for the Countess especially. Kitty remains serious, watching Levin, loving him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An impure love is not love, to me. To admire another man's wife is a pleasant thing, but sensual desire indulged for its own sake is greed, a kind of gluttony, and a misuse of something sacred which is given to us so that we may choose the one person with whom to fulfill our humanness. Otherwise we might as well be cattle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, an idealist! Reconciliatory laughter eases the atmosphere. Levin feels abashed at coming out of his shell. He steals a glance at Kitty and finds her looking at him. She smiles at him and drops her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dinner party settles in. Dolly and Karenin sit knee-to-knee in a corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . but she will be nobody's wife, she'll be ruined.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tried to save her. She chose ruin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei Aleksandrevich--look at me. You will have no peace of mind until you forgive her. It was Anna who taught me that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not wish to forgive. I am not a cruel man. I have never hated anyone. But I hate her with all my soul for all the wrong she has done me. Levin and Kitty are at the card table, with a spillage of the alphabet pieces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your turn to play us something, Countess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since we last met, there is something I have often wanted to ask you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that? Levin sorts through the alphabet pieces as though he is putting off the moment, but he quickly puts four letters spaced out in a row: D N M N.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This. Kitty tries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do Not . . . Levin adds an I next to the D.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did. Did Not. Levin shakes his head. He adds an E next to the second N. Kitty concentrates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last word is Never. Levin nods. Kitty puts letters in place. They read DID NO MEAN NEVER. Levin looks into her eyes. Kitty finds letters and presents Levin with T I D N K. Levin adds NOW to the K. Kitty nods. Levin adds OT to the N. Kitty nods. Levin adds an O to the D. Kitty shakes her head. She puts an H after the T.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what it says. Dolly, looking across the room, sees Kitty and Levin serious and smiling, rapt. Levin places extra letters: THEN I DID NOT KNOW. Kitty nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then. But now? Kitty finds C Y F A F.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can You. Kitty nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you Forgive. And Forget. Levin puts down I L Y.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never stopped . . . He looks up to see silent tears streaming down her face. His own eyes flood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin walks away from the Oblonsky house. He lifts his face to meet the snowflakes. He looks tortured. Snow melts on his face like tears. He takes from his wallet a telegram.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP TELEGRAM:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . I NEED YOUR FORGIVENESS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Die, then. He stands in the snow, uncertain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN (MOSCOW TO ST. PETERSBURG)--NIGHT Karenin sits like a statue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin is let into the house by Kapitonich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is your mistress?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Safely delivered of a daughter, Your Excellency.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So . . . she is well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mistress is very poorly. The doctor . . . Karenin, going to the stairs, sees Vronsky's cloak and cap on the coat stand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin comes up the staircase. When he reaches his dressing room he hears Anna shouting for "Alexei" in her delirium. He hesitates. Anna shouts the name again. Karenin enters Anna's boudoir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANNA'S BOUDOIR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY Karenin sees Vronsky sitting with his hands over his face. Vronsky jumps up in confusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's dying. Please let me stay. Karenin looks at him coldly and enters the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: BEDROOM LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY

result.heading: ANNA'S BOUDOIR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: Anna is not seeing or hearing, struggling against the Doctor and the Mid- wife, while Annushka holds her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank God! She talks only of you. In her delirium, Anna keeps up a bright prattle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why doesn't he come? He is kind. He will forgive me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's here--look--look--can't you see him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want Alexei! Why doesn't he come? Give me some water. No, I mustn't, it's not good for my little girl. Or let her have a nurse. Yes--don't bring her here, because Alexei is coming and it will hurt him to see her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's come, my dear--look there . . . Annushka gives way to Karenin, who kneels by the bed, taking Anna's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More ice. Annushka hurries out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, what nonsense. I must be asleep, that's what it is. You think he won't forgive me but you don't know him. No one knows him except me. I'm not afraid of him now. Karenin gazes at her. He looks at her as he's never looked at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid of death, though. Karenin tries to speak but cannot. He starts making shushing noises as to a baby. She quietens down. She seems to recognise him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my dear. Don't look at me like that. I am not the one you think. I'm afraid of her. She fell in love with another man. I'm the real one. But I'm dying now, then she'll be dead, too. Poor man! Let him come in. Alexis! Alexis!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BOUDOIR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY Vronsky hears her calling. He comes into the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky covers his face, unmanned. The Doctor nods to the Midwife-- "Leave them alone." They leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take your hands away from your face. Look at my husband. He's a saint! Take his hand. Alexei--take his hands away. Karenin pulls Vronsky's fingers, and holds on to Vronsky's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive him, too. Thank God, thank God . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna is asleep. Karenin is alone with her. The crisis seems to be over. She opens her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you came. Karenin puts his face down to her shoulder. She strokes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I had died as I wanted, you would be free of your troubles at last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am free of them. Anna closes her eyes and sleeps again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin comes in. Vronsky is there. He looks up abjectly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you think of me, please believe me, I love her--I could not have done other- wise than what I . . . what I did. Karenin nods and sits next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you must leave now. I promise to send for you if she asks for you. I don't know what happened. I forgive you. I forgive Anna. My soul is filled with joy. I will remain with her and look after her for ever. Karenin stands up and offers his hand. Vronsky grasps it and starts shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come now, come now . . . Karenin embraces him, comforting him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY FLAT, ST. PETERSBURG Vronsky arrives back at his flat . . . and finds his mother waiting for him in his sitting room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at you. You look like what you are. A laughingstock. I fancy you are to be asked to leave the regiment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would like you to go, Maman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will go when I'm ready to go. A little affair with a married woman puts a finish- ing touch to a young man's education--but this morbid, selfish obsession . . . ! You have publicly humiliated a man who has devoted his life to Russia, and it will not be forgot- ten. You'd better come back to Moscow with me. You're finished here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In Petersburg? (he taps his breastbone) I'm finished here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the first time, Vronsky is wearing civilian clothes . . . looking reflect- ingly at his uniform hanging in his wardrobe. He places his cavalry cap carefully on a shelf and closes the wardrobe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, OBLONSKY HOUSE, MOSCOW-- DAY Levin is half-dressed in clothes to be married in, assisted by Matvey and watched over by Oblonsky, who is in wedding clothes. Levin is frantic. Oblonsky is perplexed. Matvey is unflappable, holding Levin's coat ready and following him around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . no, I'll go to her and tell her it's not too late to stop this business! Better now than when we're married and she realises she doesn't love me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she does love you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can she? I mean, look at me! Suppose she's only marrying me to get married? Suppose she's still in love with Vronsky? She's making a terrible mistake! I'll go to her and tell her she's free, that's what I must do . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your coat, sir. Levin snatches the coat and puts it on, and dashes out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ENTRANCE HALL, SHCHERBATSKY HOUSE-- DAY Levin, in disarray, is let into the house. The entrance hall is crowded, loud and chaotic with children, maids, governesses and Kitty's mother. Tanya, Masha and Lili are bridesmaids. Grisha is a page. Princess Shcherbatsky, trying to create order among last-minute bouquet distribution, hair- adjustments, shoe-changing, etc., sees Levin and explodes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Konstantin!--what-- ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to talk to Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not allowed to see her! Levin gallops up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty, dressed for the church, is whispering into the crack of the bedroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I don't understand at all! What's the matter with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't love me. Think it over! Let people say what they like!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you mad? Have you changed your mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. If you don't love me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I do love you! Levin hesitates, desperate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you? Well, I love you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Konstantin! They link hands through the opening, each with a hand to kiss.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: OUTSIDE KITTY'S ROOM, SAME TIME--DAY LEVIN

direction.raw_text: . CHURCH--DAY A mere fragment of a long and ornate marriage ceremony . . . The grizzled Priest lights two decorated candles, holding them askew in his left hand, and he uses his right hand to touch Levin and, more tenderly, Kitty. He gives the couple the candles, Kitty taking hers in her gloved hand. Levin looks blissfully at Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Priest lifts crowns from their heads, and invites them to kiss each other, relieving them of their candles. The Choir bursts with pride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The baby girl, two months old, is being fed by a Wet Nurse. Replete, the baby is given over to the Nursemaid who lays the child in her crib. Karenin watches all this. The women ignore him: they are used to him now, and Karenin is harmless. Karenin stares fascinated at the baby, who stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG-- DAY Anna stares at herself in the mirror. The act of raising a pair of scissors is an effort. She isolates a thick lock of her hair, and snips it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna's hair is short all over. She sits up in bed, listening to Princess Betsy, who has brought the current gossip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . and there was her husband wearing her best ballgown, rouge all over his face . . . ma chere, le scandale! . . . But I'd better tell you some regimental news . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ENTRANCE HALL, KARENIN HOUSE--DAY Karenin enters and sees a glamorous Footman standing in the entrance hall, holding a white fur cape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Princess Elisabeth Federovna Tverskaya, Your Excellency.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karenin approaches the bedroom door. anna (O.C.) No--I don't want to see him. betsy (O.C.) . . . but your husband surely wouldn't . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna sees Karenin who is about to retreat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please excuse me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No--stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am so glad to see you. Everyone asks after you. Karenin bows to her and kisses Anna's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look feverish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have been talking too much--so I'm going.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Princess Betsy came to tell me . . . I don't want to hide anything from you . . . Count Vronsky asked to come to say goodbye--he's going away. I have said I can't receive him. Betsy kisses Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, my treasure. Karenin follows Betsy out. Anna gives in to a moment of grief, and recovers herself when she hears the crack of Karenin's knuckles. He comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree with you. As he is going away, there is no need for Count Vronsky to come here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have just said so, so there's no need to repeat it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it is for you to decide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, and I decided.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I am very glad that--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That we agree, so perhaps we can stop talk- ing about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Is there anything I can do for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, can you please please please stop crack- ing your knuckles. (PAUSE) I'm a bad woman. But I can't breathe. Your kindness which I can't repay, and your
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You begged me for my forgiveness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I didn't die and now I have to live with it! If only you would have gone on hating me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But then--what? What? What do you want? Do you know what you want? Do you want to see Count Vronsky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to say goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to say goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You would be lost. Irretrievably lost. You would have no position. And worse if we divorce. You would be the guilty party. That means you cannot legally remarry. Your union with Count Vronsky would be illegitimate, and so would your daughter who now has the protection of my name. And that is what you want! It would be a sin to help you destroy yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You forget something. Count Vronsky and I love each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this love sanctifies a criminal folly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All I know is that I sent him away and it's as if I'd shot myself through the heart!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. And Serozha . . . ? It's the crux for Anna, and she is prepared for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would die for him, but I won't live like this for him. When he knows about love, he'll forgive me. Karenin can see where this takes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I must choose the smaller sin. Vronsky robbed me of my cloak and I will give him my coat. I will give you grounds to divorce me, and I'll accept the scandal, the humilia- tion and the consequences to my career.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No . . . I can't . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may write to him but I would prefer you not to see him until you have left this house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROAD BRIDGE, ST. PETERSBURG--DAY Two coaches, each with considerable luggage, have a rendezvous, one coach on the bridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COACH, SAME TIME-- DAY Anna is holding Baby Anya. Annushka and the Nurse are with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky, in civilian clothes, is alone, looking anxiously out of the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COACH, SAME TIME-- DAY Anna gives the baby to the Nurse, as the coach halts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna gets out of her coach and runs the few yards to Vronsky's coach. He opens the door for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna is kissing Vronsky's face and being kissed, weeping, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look like a boy. But so pale. We'll go south . . . to the sea air and sunshine . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM ("THE SOUTH")--DAY Early morning. In a big untidy bed, Vronsky and Anna lie asleep, naked and satiated. The style of the room, and the warmth of the light, tell of the journey made, confirmed by the view from the window, an attractive panorama from an elevation above the sea. In the room, there are open, unpacked or partly unpacked trunks and cases, and, abandoned untidily, Anna's and Vronsky's clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slyudin is in attendance on Karenin at his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . and Madame Odette in person, so to speak, Your Excellency, with your permission . . . A respectful cough at the door reveals an obsequious male Shopkeeper. Kar- enin is bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame Odette . . . ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse the liberty, Your Excellency . . . it's for a bonnet and some ribbons Her Excel- lency has overlooked. If you wish us to address ourselves to Her Excellency, please be so good as to tell us where we might . . . Karenin is stricken into immobility, his face hiding in one propped-up hand. A tear falls on the blotter. Slyudin rescues him, ushering the Shopkeeper out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess Lydia arrives in full fluttering cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have forced my way in! I have heard!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess, every shopkeeper has heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dear friend! Don't give way to sorrow. Our Lord Jesus Christ has you in his care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm done for. I don't understand any- thing. All day long I'm being asked to make decisions about bills and servants, the kitchen, Serozha's clothes . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. I understand everything. I am going to act. The household arrangements you can leave to me. I will come every day. I will be a second mother to Serozha. He clasps both her hands and kisses them. Lydia falls to her knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He that humbleth himself shall be exalted! You must not thank me. Thank Him whose love pours through me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SNOWY COUNTRYSIDE, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME--DAY The sleigh brings Levin and Kitty home through deep snow all around. The house comes into view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have been on honeymoon travels, attested by hotel labels on the lug- gage. Kitty, eager and anxious, looks at the approaching house. Not too bad. Levin takes her hand. She smiles at him, to calm him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Agafia and Vasili come out on the porch. The house has been painted, the window frames smartened up, and paper flowers are tied to the posts of the porch. The sleigh pulls up. Levin carries Kitty through the snow to the porch. Agafia bobs. Vasili bows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Agafia, and Vasili, the steward . . . My wife, Ekaterina Alexandrovna Levin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am very pleased to meet you both. Kuzma sidles by with a bow and goes to take the luggage from the sleigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that was Kuzma. Come inside!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Careful--door's still a bit . . . (to Levin's look) it's all right, it'll be dry tomorrow . . .
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: SITTING ROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: SITTING ROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . SITTING ROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY Levin shows Kitty in. He is immensely relieved. It never looked better. At the same time he realises that Agafia is agitated: a word in private.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it all right? Kitty nods, smiles gamely--it's not like home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down a minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No--I want to see everything. Agafia panics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A moment. Levin follows Agafia out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Agafia follows Levin up the stairs. She is outraged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . and now I'm doing kitchen maid's work because Nadya's parents won't let her set foot in this house, and who can blame them!--it's indecent!
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY Levin enters the small bedroom. Agafia waits outside. Nikolai is in the bed-- wasted, near death. He lies in squalor. Masha is wiping his face. She stands up at Levin's approach. Levin bends over Niko- lai, presses his gaunt hand. Nikolai opens his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me, Konstantin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, good. The doctor here is useless--get me a doctor from Moscow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you go? I asked for you every- where, when I was getting married. Nikolai sighs and closes his eyes. Levin retreats, looks to Masha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry . . . I couldn't leave him. I know I've done wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. My wife . . . You can't stay now. Levin goes outside to Agafia and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't go against Nikolai Dmitrich's orders . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes--yes . . . She's going. An unwelcome thought strikes Levin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did the doctor see her? Agafia nods guiltily.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: OUTSIDE GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY AGAFIA

direction.raw_text: Kitty has remained. Levin, in miserable agony, is sitting holding her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will nurse him with Agafia . . . The woman will find somewhere in the village. You won't see her. She knows it's impossible for you to meet her. It is a torment to me that I have brought you under the same roof
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as this unfortunate . . . this fallen . . . and in your precious, in your delicate condition . . . Kitty detaches herself abruptly and leaves the room. He hears her going upstairs. After a moment, he follows.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: OUTSIDE GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: OUTSIDE GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . OUTSIDE GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME-- DAY Kitty comes out of the Guest Bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. A clean nightshirt and sheets. A towel and a clean pail of warm water. Ask Agafia for vinegar, and to prepare a bed somewhere for Masha. Wait. Kitty goes back into the room and returns at once with a chamber-pot which she thrusts at Levin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And bring the perfume bottle in the outside pocket of my handbag. She goes back into the room and doesn't return. Levin, humbled, goes down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nikolai has been stripped. Masha washes his body. Kitty enters with her arms full of clean linen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nikolai lies naked in clean sheets. Masha hauls him up into a sitting posi- tion. Kitty puts a nightshirt over his head. Nikolai protests feebly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not looking. Masha and Kitty pull the nightshirt over his body. Kitty pulls the sheet up over him. Masha adjusts the fresh pillow. She combs his hair (and beard).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nikolai lies quietly in a neat bed in the neat room, with medicine and water jug, etc., tidily by the bed. Masha keeps vigil by candlelight, holding his hand, singing to him quietly.
direction.name: direction
