direction.raw_text: I'm going . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin comes into the room he shared with his brother. The room has been abandoned for years . . . two bare beds, a washstand, a wooden chest. It contains a jumble of books, shoes, a pair of skates. Levin hears sleigh bells arriving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sleigh draws up, bringing a Priest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GUEST ROOM, POKROVSKOE--DAY Levin, feeling out of place, is at the washstand. He notices there is a prettily wrapped new cake of soap. He picks it up and puts it to his nose. Masha and Kitty are kneeling by the bed. The Priest bends over Nikolai holding up an icon in front of Nikolai's face and murmuring the prayers. Levin, embarrassed, puts down the soap and comes forward and kneels too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nikolai is at the point of death. Levin stares, torn between the mystery and the lack of mystery, the ordinariness of the body finally wearing out. The death rattle comes. Masha kisses the dead hand. The Priest continues to murmur. Kitty takes hold of Masha's hand. Levin stares into Nikolai's face: if this is death, what is life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nikolai lies dead, candles burning at his head and feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levin counts money, for the services of the Priest . . . who is eating bread and soup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Father . . . and how much . . . ? He offers a handful of paper money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At your benevolence. It is a custom, not a levy, Your Excellency . . . Jesus overturned the money-tables outside the temple, but . . . He shrugs and puts the money away, and returns to his soup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The snow is almost gone. Nikolai's grave has flowers strewn on the mound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pava's yearling and several more calves, delirious with release, mill through the yard with the herd, to pasture, with a Herdsman and Laska urging them on. Masha is leaving, alone behind the Coachman. She sits quietly and doesn't look back. Levin and Kitty watch her drive away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're such an expert on love, Kostya . . . why didn't you know it when you saw it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GOVERNMENT BUILDING, SAME TIME-- DAY Lydia hurries along grand deserted hallways. She knows her way. A door ahead of her opens and a dozen Politicians and Civil Servants carrying portfolios cross her path, with Stremov at the centre of their unheard conver- sation. Stremov is smiling, triumphant. Lydia expects to see Karenin among them. She hurries on to the door they came from.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COMMITTEE CHAMBER, SAME TIME--DAY When Lydia enters, Karenin, alone in the chamber, is sitting immobile, defeated. He starts gathering his papers. Lydia comes to him. Her agitation explained, she takes an opened letter from her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei, they're back! Here in St. Petersburg! She has written to me. Karenin accepts the letter and reads it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To you? . . . I think I don't have the right to refuse . . . It's the boy's birthday . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My friend . . . you would be blowing on the embers of a fire which must be allowed to die . . . Let me write to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--DAY Anna is looking into the display window of a toy shop. She is excited, glow- ing. She enters the shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--DAY Returning from the toy shop with a wrapped parcel, Anna comes in. Luggage is stacked up in the hallway and Franz is unpacking stuff in the main room. She sees that a hand-delivered letter is waiting for her. She opens it. Anna reads the letter. For a moment she is devastated by it--but then, furious, she tears it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KARENIN HOUSE, ST. PETERSBURG--DAY It's very early morning. The street is not awake. A hired cab brings Anna to her former home. She is heavily veiled, and carries the wrapped parcel from the toy shop. The cab is to wait for her. She rings the doorbell. A sleepy Servant opens the big wooden door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here to see Sergei Alexeyich. The young Servant doesn't know her. Anna steps past him, pushing money into his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kapitonich, pulling on his livery greatcoat, comes to the inner glass door and lets Anna in. He does not recognise her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have brought something for Sergei Alexeyich. Kapitonich scrutinises her, prepared to forestall her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is not up yet. Would you wish to wait? Who shall I say . . . ? Kapitonich peers at her and realises who she is. He steps back and bows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please come in, Your Excellency.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna goes quickly to the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allow me to announce you. The tutor may be there and not dressed. Anna shakes her head and is almost running away from him. Kapitonich gives chase.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: ENTRANCE HALL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: Please allow me!
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: STAIRS, KARENIN'S HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY KAPITONICH

result.ToD: UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY Anna dashes past two Housemaids who gape at her, and disappears round the corner. She's a little mad now.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY Anna, wild-eyed, climbs the stairs and meets the tutor, Vasily Lukich, coming down, buttoning his waistcoat. Lukich is startled, not knowing her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've come to see Sergei Alexeyich. Kapitonich reaches these stairs, calling, "Your Excellency . . . !"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TOP FLOOR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY Anna dashes for Serozha's door and flings herself through it.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: TOP FLOOR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: TOP FLOOR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: It's no longer Serozha's room. A large Woman sits up in bed. She's probably the Cook. She cries out. Anna reels back. She looks panicked. Kapitonich catches up, out of breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's been moved to the small sitting room.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY At the bottom of the Upper Stairs, Lukich, the Housemaids and a couple of half-dressed Footmen have their heads together. They move aside as Anna hurries by, seeing nothing.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY Kapitonich catches up with Anna at the door of the "small sitting room."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll just look in. Anna shakes her head and walks past him, into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY The curtains are drawn closed. The room is dim. Anna sees Serozha sitting up, yawning, his eyes closed, and falling back on the pillow. She comes to the bed and whispers his name. Serozha raises himself on his elbow, opens his eyes and smiles dreamily and falls forward into her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my dear little boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew you would come. Today is my birthday. Serozha rubs his face on her neck, falls back on the pillow, only half awake and going back to sleep. Anna looks at him avidly, touching his forearms, his shoulders, the hair over his ears. She can't stop her own tears. He comes awake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you crying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't cry. It's time for you to get dressed. And I almost forgot your present, look . . . open it . . . Serozha takes off her hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't want that . . . Let me see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Serozha tears open the package, lifts the lid of the cardboard box and finds a puppet, a beautifully dressed marionette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, he's grand!
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY Korney, the Valet, among others, has joined the "conference" and is blaming Kapitonich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your fault for letting her in!--you should be sacked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes, you would have sent her packing! Ten years I've been keeping the door and the mistress was always kind to me. You should stick to stealing the master's clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've had enough of this--it's my job to get the boy out of bed before His Excellency comes . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lukich cautiously opens the door. He sees mother and son working the pup- pet and laughing quietly. Lukich backs off. Anna looks round to see the door closing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling Kutik, Maman can't stay . . . Serozha clings to Anna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't go!--he's not coming yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I must, and you must love Papa-- he's better than I am. When you're grown-up . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one in the whole world is better than you. Anna hugs him.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: SEROZHA'S ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--DAY

result.ToD: OUTSIDE SEROZHA'S ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY
result.heading: OUTSIDE SEROZHA'S ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY

direction.raw_text: . OUTSIDE SEROZHA'S ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME-- DAY The Servants in a huddle look round at the sound of a door, and approach- ing footsteps round a blind corner. There is no one in view when Karenin comes around the corner. The Ser- vants have vanished. He goes to Serozha's door. Anna comes out. He stops, astonished. Anna looks at him boldly, then pulls down her veil. Karenin bows. Anna walks past him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S FLAT, ST. PETERSBURG--DAY Anna comes "home" from Karenin's house. The visit has changed her. She sits down in her hat and coat. Annushka comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Anya?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's still asleep. Should I take your coat? Anna shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you feeling unwell, Madame?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sleeping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can send out for something. Anna nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twilight. Anna appears not to have moved. The baby is heard crying in another room. Anna's face remains set, but she reacts on hearing Vronsky coming in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you in the dark? He turns on a gaslight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yashvin is going to call . . . you remember him. (about her clothes) Are you going out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To where? To whom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know what happened to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I told you yesterday . . . My brother . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it take all day for you to meet your brother? Does he need you more than I do? Vronsky sits next to her and puts his arms round her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happened? Anna shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well . . . Alexander agreed to everything. Mother's house in Moscow will go to him, and the country estate will be our new home . . . as soon as the divorce . . . Karenin hasn't answered your letter yet? Anna shakes her head. She stands up at last and takes off her hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S FLAT, ST. PETERSBURG--NIGHT Yashvin is a welcome visitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's wonderful to have you both returned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How good you are to come. You're the very first person to call on me since our return. Yashvin gets the point of that. He is embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I received a note from Princess Betsy asking me if I'd call on her between six-thirty and eight. Or was it seven? Yashvin got the point of that, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alas, between six-thirty and seven is just when I'm unable to see her!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But perhaps you'll meet at the opera tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would love to be there if I could get a box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame, your box is number four! You'll find me there with Princess Myagkaya. Will you come, Vronsky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky shakes his head. Yashvin kisses Anna's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see why . . . Alexei is so fond of you. Yashvin laughs and bows himself out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know you can't go to the theatre?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annushka!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For heaven's sake-- Annushka comes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bath. I'll come in and choose a dress. Annushka goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna--I implore you--don't you know . . . ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not ashamed of who I am or what I've done: are you ashamed for me? Why do you keep a room at the hotel? Aren't we together? Have you changed towards me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's because I love you and care about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If that's the case, I don't know why you aren't coming with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That would make it worse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're afraid. Well, I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT Before the performance, the stairs, galleries and corridors, giving access to the stalls and boxes, are crowded with the town's highest society. And Anna, at her most beautiful, is magically cleaving through it. Awareness of her presence is like a contagion, and yet everyone manages not to catch her eye . . . so while all around her there are people impeding each other with greetings, Anna's path opens before her. She knows what is happening. It shocks her but her eyes barely show it. The spell is broken by Princess Myagkaya (she of the 85 kopek sauce) who hails her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna . . . ! She picks up on the surrounding effect of this, and rubs it in with mischief, taking Anna's arm. princess myagkaya (cont'd) Something has done you good--you look wonderful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VRONSKY'S FLAT, ST PETERSBURG--NIGHT Vronsky sits and broods. Angrily, he changes his mind. He jumps up call- ing for Franz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT Vronsky's cab draws up outside the brightly lit, deserted opera house. He alights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky comes up the stairs. The place is deserted, apart from Atten- dants . . . one of whom takes Vronsky's cloak and gives him a token.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: ANNA'S BOX, OPERA HOUSE, SAME TIME-- NIGHT
result.heading: ANNA'S BOX, OPERA HOUSE, SAME TIME-- NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . ANNA'S BOX, OPERA HOUSE, SAME TIME-- NIGHT On stage, Act One is just ending, and the curtain falls. The applause gives way to chatter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should we visit or stay put? Anna sees Vronsky entering on the side-aisle below. He looks up at the boxes, seeking her. She turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay put. Princess Myagkaya has engaged the attention of Stremov in the neighbour- ing box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minister! Congratulations. Come in for a moment. But Stremov only bows coldly and turns away. Yashvin notes this and begins to chew his moustache anxiously. Anna's neighbour on the other side, a meek husband of a battle-axe, admires her openly. Anna sees that Vronsky has stopped to talk to Countess Vronsky and the Princesses Sorokina. The young Princess seems animated by Vronsky, who bows himself away. Princess Myagkaya sees where Anna is looking. princess myagkaya (cont'd) Princess Sorokina and her daughter, they're from Moscow, neighbours of Countess Vron- sky, quite well off, no sons, she's a widow. Anna gives her a smiling but wounded look. princess myagkaya (cont'd) My dear, I'm a sales catalogue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky meets Alexander in the aisle and greets him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll come up to see us afterwards . . . ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talk to Varya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexander indicates his seat to Vronsky. Vronsky sits by Varya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you call on Anna?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Alexei . . . I'm fond of you . . . but . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For God's sake, Anna isn't a criminal!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd call on her if she'd only broken the law. But she broke the rules. Vronsky is angry and offended. He gets up, bows to Varya. When he looks up, he sees Betsy beckoning to him from her box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna watches Vronsky, sees him acknowledge Betsy's summons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who has made the decor? Haven't we got a programme? Colonel, would you be so kind . . . ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Anna's neighbour, emboldened, offers her his programme.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please . . . I would be honoured if you would take mine . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, how very . . . The Neighbour's Wife, catching this, reacts as though electrocuted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Princess Betsy is smoking. Prince Tverskoy is examining an ancient book. Vronsky enters the box. He bows to the Prince, and kisses Betsy's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Catullus, printed in Venice, 1501 . . . remarkable. A grovelling House Manager appears in their midst, to tell Betsy she can't smoke in the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A thousand apologies, Princess, but . . . Princess Betsy blows smoke and hands the cigarette, in its holder, to a figure standing quietly in the shadowy corner of the box: Makhotin. Makhotin takes the cigarette from the holder, crushes it in his left palm. He feels humiliated . . . but that's love. The House Manger bows and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Captain Makhotin . . . The Angry Wife's voice cuts through the audience chatter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a disgrace! Take me home! Vronsky turns round to look. He sees the Husband trying to calm his Wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fetch my cloak! Vronsky sees Anna looking straight ahead. Yashvin is eating his moustache.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene next door is a social catastrophe for Anna, but she is riding it. Princess Myagkaya takes her hand. Yashvin shrinks into his corner, morti- fied. The whole opera house is becoming aware of the "scandal." The Angry Wife has raised her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we coming to? The Husband has succeeded in putting his wife's cloak over her shoulders. Her exit line is for the benefit of the entire audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this the opera house or a--or a French music hall-- ?! The Wife and her Husband leave the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BETSY'S OPERA BOX, SAME TIME--NIGHT Vronsky is tormented. He moves to leave the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, why don't you? Rescue her and put your seal on the fiasco. Vronsky knows it and is trapped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alexei . . . you see why she must divorce. Marriage will solve everything. When will it be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As far as I'm concerned, she's my wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, as you saw, she isn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to Moscow, and then to my place in the country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That sounds like a good idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But for a day or two, Anna will be at home, at my flat. Betsy shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, I'll say goodbye now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PETERSBURG--NIGHT Angry and upset, Anna sweeps into the flat in her opera cloak. Vronsky follows her in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . you had an excellent night! Does your mother want you to marry the widow or the child?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Either one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't make a joke of it. If you loved me, you would have locked me in to stop me going. She throws aside her cloak and goes into the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annushka, asleep in a chair, waiting loyally, wakes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to bed. Vronsky comes in as Annushka goes out. He comes to Anna and puts his arms round her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it was my fault.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know how to make you sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky makes love to Anna but it's not working for her. Her eyes stray around. By the bed is a carafe of water, an empty glass and a pharmacy bottle as dark as ink, with a handwritten label.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: High summer. Heat and dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna, with some dainty shopping by her, is taking tea in a genteel cafe. Her eye is caught by a mother and son at another table. The boy is a "Serozha." Anna misses her son acutely in that moment. Then Dolly enters the tea shop. Anna's heart lifts for a moment and she is about to greet her, but then realises that Dolly is one of a trio of "society ladies," and Anna lowers her head. When she sneaks a look, she catches one of the ladies whispering to the others. Anna realises that she has been recognised by a stranger, and is notorious. She "hides" in her purse, finding money to leave on the table so that she can escape. A sound makes her look up and she sees that Dolly has sat down opposite her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna . . . I am very glad to see you. Are you well? How is your little one? Anna nods, words won't come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stiva wanted to invite you and Count Vron- sky to the house but it's impossible . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no--you don't. Kitty and her husband are with us. She's in Moscow to have the baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty . . . ? Oh, tell her how pleased I am . . . !
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps I'll wait a year or two. (she gulps a laugh) Oh . . . love!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes . . . love! Don't you disapprove of me for what I've done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I wish I'd done the same. But no one asked me! Well . . . I wouldn't have been brave enough. (she blinks tears) Stiva, you know . . . he doesn't change . . . like all men, I suppose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't notice her tactlessness but it lands on Anna, who manages a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL SUITE, MOSCOW--NIGHT Anna, in a nightdress, is awake in the night, staring out of the grand window of a grand hotel, smoking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna comes back to bed. Vronsky is asleep. She unstops a pharmacy bottle (a different one) and pours a draught mixed with water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna sleeps alone in the bed. Annushka, after a tap on the door, comes in cautiously, worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madame . . . Madame . . . Anna sits up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you ill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What time is it? Is Anya up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's afternoon, Madame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm all right. It's all right. (PAUSE) Get them to bring up all our trunks and travel cases. We've been here long enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky comes in, noting the empty trunks and cases stacked up. Anna comes from her room to greet him. She is making an effort to be pleasant, but she looks excited, febrile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had an inspiration. Why do we have to wait here? Why can't we wait in the coun- try? I don't want to hear any more about a divorce, or think about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good! I'm bored here. When should we go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I bore you here, I'll bore you in the country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't say you bore me. Moscow bores me. When should we go? . . . Tomorrow? But Anna's mood has turned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't be ready by tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The day after, then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, wait. That's Sunday. I have to see Maman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's twenty minutes away in the train-- you could go to see her tomorrow--or was it that you wanted to spend Sunday with Princess Sorokina?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please don't spoil everything. I can't see Maman tomorrow because she won't have read the papers she has to sign. Oh, and then there's the bank . . . But we can leave on Tuesday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In that case, let's not bother. I'll leave on Sunday or not at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's absurd!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's absurd to you because you have no understanding for my life here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna . . . Anna . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've stopped loving me. You've given up everything for me, and it's turned you against me. Why lie about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop. I put off our departure for a day or two, and you tell me I don't love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I've been living off your love and there's none left, so this is over! Finished. She leaves him, slamming the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna comes in and lies down on the bed, closes her eyes, sits up, pours a dose from the medicine bottle by the bed, and lies down. Vronsky comes in. He takes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. I don't mind when we go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll telegraph Maman. We'll go on Sunday. I'll do anything you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should leave me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to. I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't ask why about love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna comes straight from bed. She is drugged and shaky. The room is empty but there is a coffee tray on the table. Anna feels the coffeepot and pours herself a cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky is at his desk. Anna enters with her coffee. Vronsky is reading a telegram. Seeing her enter, he puts the telegram under his papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So--will you be all packed? I'll be out today making the arrangements.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that your way of telling me you'll be at your mother's with that simpering little princess?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I'll be with my lawyers. I'm waiting for some documents. Then I'm having dinner to say goodbye to old comrades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I know what that means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My God, this is unendurable. He controls himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can invite them here if you like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, but if I'm not fit to dine in soci- ety, I won't eat with the band. Who was the telegram from? Vronsky retrieves the telegram and hands it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't show it to you, because Stiva keeps telegraphing what we already know. Kare- nin promises nothing, but will consider . . . Anna tosses the telegram aside unread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you I don't care about the divorce, so why hide the telegram? What else do you hide from me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hide nothing from you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you care about the divorce? What has it got to do with us loving each other?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Until we're married, our daughter is legally Karenin's. I care about it because we need to be free to marry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're perfectly free to marry anyone your mother wants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we aren't talking about--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, we are, and, by the way, compared to your mother I'm the Virgin Mary. Vronsky is silent with anger. He gets up and goes out, returning with his hat in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there anything you wish to say to me? She remains silent. He leaves again. She lights a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL BUILDING, SAME TIME--DAY The Sorokina Coach draws up outside the door. The coach with its crest and the Coachman's livery (a bright yellow cockade) are highly distinctive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna, with her cup of coffee, comes in and looks down from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky, hat in hand, at the coach window, accepts a large envelope from a lilac-gloved hand. He bows. With a wave of the hand and a flash of golden hair, the coach pulls away. Vronsky goes back inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the envelope, Vronsky comes in. Anna is as he left her, the cigarette stubbed out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So it's the child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She brought papers from Maman. He hesitates, thinking she is about to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna? She stays silent. He leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, HOTEL SUITE, SAME TIME--DAY Anna finds Annushka filling several half-filled cases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unpack everything. We're not going. She lies down on the bed. Annushka would like to comfort her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna Arkadyeva . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When Count Vronsky comes back, tell him . . . I don't want to be disturbed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna is listening for Vronsky's return. She hears him come in. She hears him approach. Then she hears Annushka's voice, then Vronsky's voice. She waits in suspense, disappointed as Vronsky's steps retreat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna, holding a candle-lamp, finds Vronsky asleep on the couch. She hesi- tates, but turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna wakes. She re-collects herself. She looks at the bedside clock. In a sud- den hurry she leaves the bed and the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OUTSIDE THE BEDROOM, HOTEL SUITE, SAME TIME--DAY Anna finds Annushka waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Count Vronsky . . . ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He went out early, to the stables, he said. Anna collapses on a chair and weeps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Annushka . . . I should have died. Do you remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't take it to heart, Anna Arkadyeva . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've made him hate me.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: OUTSIDE THE BEDROOM, HOTEL SUITE, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE (HOTEL)--DAY Anna's hand writes in a hurry: "I'm to blame. Come home. I'm frightened."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna seals the note and gives it to Annushka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Michael to hurry. Annushka runs out with the note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna is keeping watch at the window . . . and is rewarded by the return- ing coach. She hurries out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna looks down into the entrance hall. Michael, the Coachman, comes in and comes up the stairs to her. She sees that he is holding her note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Count Vronsky had already left, Your Excel- lency. He took a cab to the station . . . to the Countess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna clutches her red bag to her, sitting among passengers. Anna looks about her. Across the carriage she sees through the window that her train is overtaking another passenger train on the next line. She looks at the windows of the other train "going by" . . . seeing the pas- sengers inside. Unexpectedly, she seems to see a Man who might be Vronsky sitting opposite a laughing Woman who might be Princess Sorokina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna's body jerks involuntarily. She half rises. The image, however, is brief and is borne away, as her own train goes by, accelerating. The win- dows opposite pick up speed as she leaves them behind-- And then she has the same illusion again-- a "Vronsky" and a "Sorokina" glimpsed in the other train and snatched away in the instant. Now she stands up and goes to the opposite window, where the windows of the other train are flashing by in the (anachronistic) manner of pro- jected film-frames, and she sees "Vronskys" and "Sorokinas" flashing by at gathering speed. And then the train has gone and there's nothing going by but the view. Anna collapses into the nearest seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train arrives at a small station. Anna steps down from the train. The platform is well populated by people waiting to board the train or to meet the arriving passengers. There is an energy about the people-- shouting, laughter, movement. Porters shout for custom. A couple of Young Men seem to be laughing rudely directly at her, but they pass by, ignoring her. Anna pauses, bewildered, lost, not knowing what to do next. She sees the Sorokina Coachman on the platform, recognising his distinctive livery, a cockade in his hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you waiting for the Princess Sorokina?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Your Excellency, both princesses are at the house of Countess Vronsky. I'm waiting
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna turns back, agitated, expecting Vronsky to appear, but what comes is a Footman carrying three hatboxes and a large box from a dress shop. Anna walks away, along the platform, impeded by people going by her, aware that some are staring at her as she passes. A Boy selling drinks grins at her. A little group of Ladies and Children meeting a bespectacled man off the train are laughing and chattering but fall silent and look at her. She increases her pace. She hurries away towards the far end of the platform. Beyond her, a goods train is slowly approaching. Between her and the train, two Maidservants are walking towards her. They turn their heads to look at her, remarking on her dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that lace on her . . . There is a rough bench near the end of the platform. Anna reaches it and sits down. The two girls turn again to look back at her, and are struck by the sight of Anna sitting alone in profile. The goods train reaches her and the first wagon goes past her. The two girls stop and watch, vaguely puzzled by her. As they watch, the beautiful woman on the bench gets up and walks the few steps to the edge of the wooden platform and into the path of the train, disappearing from view between the wheels of one of the wagons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (POKROVSKOE)--DAY
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --A SCYTHE CUTS A SWATHE THROUGH STANDING HAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RAILS--THE RED HANDBAG --lying separate against a rail, is clipped by a rolling train-wheel and knocked aside, spilling its contents . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (POKROVSKOE)--DAY A scythe cuts a swathe through standing hay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's nearly the last of the hay. The scythe is being swung by Theodore, known from last year. He is one of a dozen Mowers. Levin is among them, wielding his scythe. They have almost reached the end of the field, where the last of the hay is being pitchforked up on to the last piled cart. Theodore's daughter-in-law, now visibly pregnant, is still adept with a pitchfork. It's a lowering thundery day at the end of summer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be buying in feed before winter's over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you don't press people hard, but you live rightly, for your soul, not your belly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My soul! What's that? I know what my belly is. How do we know what's rightly? I believe in reason.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reason? And was it reason that made you chose a wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a great one for reasoning, Konstantin Dmitrich, but what's rightly is outside your mathematic--that's what's rightly about it! This stops Levin's scythe. He is illumined. Theodore swings the scythe again. Levin walks away, gives his scythe to a Labourer by the cart, and keeps walking. He quickens his pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first drops of rain, few and heavy, arrive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cries of alarm and laughter burst from a Mushrooming Party approaching the house. Children run ahead, the adults walk faster, then run, helping with baby carriages and picking up small children and baskets of mush- rooms . . . urged on from the porch by Agafia. Levin, coming from the hay field, joins the rout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The grown-ups are: Levin, Oblonsky, Dolly, the Oblonsky Nurse, Prince and Princess Shcherbatsky. The children are: Tanya, Grisha, Masha, Lili and Vasili. Dolly carries her youngest. The children are eighteen months older than when we first saw them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The heavens open as everyone gets under cover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Ekaterina Alexandrovna?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right, the mistress is giving Mitya his bath. It is evident from her tone that Kitty and Agafia have made it up long ago.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: HOUSE AND PORCH, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME--DAY

direction.raw_text: Rain on the window and on the roof. The rain is so loud that it is the foreground sound in the scene; and the dialogue, while we can pick it out without difficulty, is the background sound. Levin enters, wet. Dmitri (Mitya), two months old, is lying on his back in a basin, supported by Kitty's palm under his head. Kitty squeezes a sponge over his body, which he likes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came looking for you . . . I understood something . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what was that? Kitty lifts Mitya onto a towel on her lap, wraps him and gives him to Levin, who is enchanted by him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiled at me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's very advanced for his age. She picks up her rings to replace them on her fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you understand? But the baby starts to yell for the breast. Kitty starts to undo her blouse. Levin shakes his head: he'll tell her some other time, or maybe not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The storm has passed. Everything drips. Oblonsky comes from inside and lights a cigar. Indistinctly seen and heard through the window, the Mushrooming Party occupies the dining room. Oblonsky smokes thoughtfully, melancholy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FLOWERING MEADOW--DAY SPRINGTIME Baby Anya, old enough to stagger on her feet, wavers through wild flowers half her height. She falls over, almost disappearing. This is being watched, with a mixture more pleasure than pain, by Kar- enin. He is in early retirement, sitting with a book in a garden seat, dressed comfortably under a straw hat. There is the SOUND OVER of people playing croquet. Serozha, aged ten, enters his view, going to Anya to haul her upright, and keeping hold of her hand as she staggers on. Karenin's pleasure increases slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: this, the growing SOUND of a battlefield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vronsky, in an unfamiliar uniform, sabre pointing forward, is mounted at full gallop with the SOUND of the charge all around him in the smoke and noise of guns. Something heavy and invisible with its own SOUND--like the flap of an awning--takes him from his horse into the air and gone, leaving spouts of blood poised for an instant in the smoke.
direction.name: direction
